Attorney General Barr Delivers Remarks On China

July 16, 2020 11:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

ATTORNEY GENERAL WILLIAM P. BARR

[*]BARR: Thank you very much, Andrew, for your kind introduction and I'd like to say that I really appreciate the work that Andrew and Matt, our U.S. attorneys for the Eastern and Western District of Michigan are--are doing here for the people of Michigan, and all the law enforcement community from Michigan that is here today. We really appreciate your work.

And as Andrew said, after my remarks, they're going to put on a presentation on the China initiative which I think you'd find very interesting. So if you have the time, I--I'd urge you to--to stay for that. And I'd like to thank the--the leadership and staff of the Gerald R. Ford Presidential Museum, especially Elaine Didier for hosting this event. And also thank the Ford Presidential Foundation and its executive director, Joe Calvaruso.

Even under normal circumstances, it's hard to put together an event like this, but in the current circumstances, it's especially challenging and I really appreciate it. And I really appreciate all of you who've come--I know many have come from--from around the state and I appreciate the--the effort that was made to--to be here for these remarks. I was last in Grand Rapids, it--it'd be 30 years ago, John. John Smietanka from here was one of my principal deputies when I was deputy attorney general and stayed on while I was attorney general. He was the U.S. attorney here in the western district so, John, it's great to see you here.

I feel a special bond to the Ford administration so it's appropriate to--to be here today for these remarks because I started out in the CIA in 1973 and then President Ford took office. And because of what was going on at the agency, I had the privilege of working closely with many of the superb people that he brought into government. Many of whom I had the opportunity to work with over the years, several of whom were my--were my mentors.

One of the people I met was the attorney general at that time, Ed Levi, who President Ford had made attorney general and his portrait is up in my conference room. And his grandson, Will Levi, is my chief of staff so, as I say, I feel especially close to the--to the Ford administration. I wasn't a political appointee in that administration, many of the political appointees I've worked with over the years who really cut their--cut their teeth during the Ford administration.

I'm privileged to speak here today about what may prove to be the most important issue for our nation and the world in the 21st century and that is the United States' response in the global ambitions--to the global ambitions of the Chinese Communist Party. The CCP rules with an iron fist over one of the great ancient civilizations of the world. It seeks to leverage the immense power, productivity, and ingenuity of the Chinese people to overthrow the rule-based international system and to make the world safe for dictatorship.

How the United States responds to this challenge will have historic implications and will determine whether the United States and its liberal democratic allies will continue to shape their own destiny or whether the CCP and its autocratic tributaries will continue to--will control the future. You know since the 1890s at least, the United States has been the technological leader of the world. And from that prowess has come our prosperity, the opportunity for generations of Americans, and our security.

It's because of that that we were able to play such a pivotal role in world history by turning back the threat of fascism and the threat of communism. What's at stake these days is whether we can maintain that leadership position and that technological leadership. Are we going to be the generation that has allowed that to be stolen, which is really stealing the future of our children and our grandchildren?

Several weeks ago the national security advisor, Robert O'Brien, spoke about the CCP's ideology and global ambitions. He declared, and I agree, that the days of American passivity and nai--naivete regarding the People's Republic of China are over. And last week the FBI Director Chris Wray described how the CCP pursues its ambitions through the nefarious and even illegal conduct including industrial espionage, theft, extortion, cyberattacks, and maligned influence activities.

In the coming days you will hear from Secretary Mike Pompeo who will sum up what is at stake for the United States and the free world. Now Chris Wray told me that shortly after his speech last week one of the leaders of the Chinese Communist Party pronounced that his speech was particularly disgusting. I told him that I was going to aim today to be despicable.

(LAUGHTER)

But I'll settle for especially disgusting. But no--no matter how they (PH) Chinese seek to characterize it, I do hope that my speech and--and Mike Pompeo's speech will encourage the American people to reevaluate their relationship with China so long as it continues to be ruled by the Chinese Communist Party.

It is fitting that we're here today at the Ford Presidential Museum. Gerald Ford served in the highest ech--echelons of--of the government at the dawn of America's reengagement with China which began obviously with President Nixon in 1972. And three years' later in 1975, President Ford visited China for a summit with PRC leaders, including Mao Zedong. At the time it was unthinkable that China would emerge after the Cold War as a near peer competitor of the United States. And even then there were signs of China's immense latent power.

In the joint report of their visit to China in 1972, House Majority Leader Hale Boggs and then-minority leader Gerald Ford, wrote, "If she manages to achieve as she aspires, China in the next half century can emerge as a self-sufficient power of a billion people. This last impression of the reality of China's colossal potential is perhaps the most vivid of our journey. As our small party traveled through that boundless land, this sense of a giant stirring, a dragon waking, gave us much to ponder."

It is now nearly 50 years later, and the (INAUDIBLE) ponderings of these two congressmen have come to pass. Deng Xiaoping, whose economic reform launched China's remarkable rise, had a famous motto hide your strength, bide your time. That is precisely what China has done.

China's economy has quietly grown from about 2 percent of the world's GDP in 1980 to nearly 20 percent today and by some estimates based on purchasing power parity, the Chinese economy is already larger than ours. The General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party Xi Jinping who has centralized power to a degree not seen since the dictatorship of (INAUDIBLE) now speaks openly of China moving closer to the center stage, building a socialism that is superior to capitalism and replacing the American dream with the Chinese solution.

China is no longer hiding its strength nor biding its time. From the perspective of its communist rulers, China's time has arrived. The People's Republic of China is now engaged in an economic blitzkrieg an aggressive orchestrated whole of government indeed whole of society campaign to seize the commanding heights of the global economy and to surpass the United States as the world's preeminent technological superpower. A centerpiece of this effort is (AUDIO GAP) such as robotics and telecommunications.

It is clear that the PRC seeks not merely to join the ranks of other advanced industrial economies but to replace them altogether. Made in China 2025 is the latest iteration of the PRC's state-led mercantilist economic model. For American companies in the global marketplace, free and fair competition with China has long been a fantasy. To tilt the playing field to its advantage China's communist government has perfected a wide array of predatory and often unlawful tactics currency manipulation, tariffs, quotas, state-led strategic investment and acquisition, theft and forced transfer of intellectual property, state subsidies, dumping, cyber-attacks, and industrial espionage.

About 80 percent of all federal economic espionage prosecutions allege conduct undertaken for the benefit of the Chinese state, and about 60 percent of all trade secret theft cases have been connected to China. The PRC also seeks to dominate key trade routes and infrastructure in Eurasia, Africa, and the Pacific. In the South China Sea for example through which about one-third on the world's maritime trade passes the PRC has asserted expansive and historically dubious claims to nearly the entire waterway, flouted the rulings of international courts, built artificial islands, and placed military outpost on them and harassed its neighbors, ships and fishing boats.

Another ambitious project to spread its power and influence is the PRC's Belt and Roads infrastructure initiative. Although billed as foreign aid, in fact, these investments appear designed to serve the PRC's strategic interest and domestic economic needs. For example, the PRC has been criticized for loading port companies up with debt, refusing to renegotiate terms and then taking control of the infrastructure itself as it did with Sri Lanka--with its Sri Lankan port of Hambantota in 2017. This is little more than a form of modern-day colonialism.

Just as consequential, however, are the PRC's plans to dominate the world's digital infrastructure through its digital Silk Road initiative. I have previously spoken at length about the grave risks of allowing the world's most powerful dictatorship to build the next generation of global telecommunications networks known as 5G. Perhaps less widely known are the PRC's efforts to surpass the United States and other cutting-edge fields like artificial intelligence. Through innovation such as machine learning and big data, artificial intelligence allows machines to mimic human functions such as recognizing faces, interpreting spoken words, driving vehicles, and playing games of skill much like chess or even more complex Chinese game of Go.

In 2017, Beijing unveiled its next-generation artificial intelligence plan, a blueprint for leading the world in AI by 2030. Whichever nation emerges as the global leader in AI will be best positioned to unlock not only its considerable economic potential but a range of military applications such as the use of computer vision to gather intelligence. The PRC's drive for technological supremacy is complemented by its plan to monopolize rare earth materials, which play a vital role in industries such as consumer electronics, electric vehicles, medical devices, and military hardware.

According to the Congressional research service from the 1960s to the 1980s, the United States led the world in rare earth production. Since then, production has shifted almost entirely to China in large part due to the lower labor costs and lighter economic and environmental regulation. The United States is now dangerously dependent on the PRC for these essential materials. Overall China is America's top supplier accounting for about 80 percent of our imports. The risk of dependence are real.

In 2010, for example, Beijing cut exports of rare earth materials to Japan after an incident involving the disputed islands in the East China Sea. The PRC could do the same to us. As China's progress in these critical sectors illustrates, the PRC's predatory economic policies are succeeding. For 100 years, America's was the world's largest manufacturing allowing us to serve the world's--serve as the world's arsenal of democracy. China overtook the United States and manufacturing output in 2010; the PRC is now be world's arsenal of dictatorship. How did China accomplish all of this?

No one should underestimate the ingenuity and industry of the Chinese people. At the same time, no one should doubt that America made China's meteoric rise possible. China has reaped enormous benefits from the free flow of American aid and trade. In 1980 Congress granted the PRC most favored nation trading status. In the 1990s, American company strongly supported the PRC succession to the World Trade Organization and the permanent normalization of trade relations. Today U.S. China trade totals about $700 billion.

Last year Newsweek ran a cover story titled How America's Biggest Companies Made China Great Again. The article details tell China's communist leaders Lord American business with the promise of market access and then having profited from American investment, and know-how turned increasingly hostile. The PRC used tariffs and quotas to pressure American companies to give up their technology and form joint ventures with Chinese companies. Regulators then discriminated against American firms using tactics like holding up permits, yet few companies even Fortune 500 giants, have been willing to bring formal trade complaints for fear of angering Beijing.

Just as American companies have become dependent on Chinese markets, the United States as a whole now relies on the PRC for many vital goods and services. The COVID-19 pandemic has shown a spotlight on that dependency. For example, China is the world's largest producer of certain protective equipment, such as facemasks and medical gowns. In March, as the pandemic spread around the world, the PRC hoarded the masks for itself, blocking producers, including American companies, from exporting them to other countries that needed them.

It then attempted to exploit the shortage for propaganda purposes, shipping limited quantities of often defective equipment and then requiring foreign leaders to publicly thank Beijing for these shipments. China's dominance of the world's markets for medical goods goes beyond masks and gowns. It has become the United States' largest supplier of medical devices while at the same time discriminate--discriminating against American medical companies in China.

China's government has targeted foreign firms for greater regulatory scrutiny, instructed Chinese hospitals to buy products Made in China and pressured American firms to build factories in China where their intellectual property is more vulnerable to theft. As one expert has observed, American Medical device manufacturers are effectively creating their own competitors. America has also--also depends on Chinese supply--Chinese supply chains in other vital sectors, especially Pharmaceuticals.

America remains the global leader in drug discovery, but China is now the world's largest producer of active pharmaceutical ingredients known as APIs. As one defense health agency official noted, should China decide to limit or restrict the delivery of APIs on the United States, it could result in severe shortages of pharmaceuticals for both domestic and military uses.

To achieve dominance in pharmaceuticals, China's rulers went to the same playbook that they've used to gut other American industries. In 2008, the PRC designated pharmaceutical production as a high value added industry and boosted Chinese companies with subsidies and export tax rebates. Meanwhile, the PRC has systematically preyed on American companies. American firms well-known obstacles in the Chinese health market include drug approval delays, unfair pricing limitations, IP theft, and counterfeiting.

Chinese nationals working as employees at pharma companies have been caught stealing trade secrets both in America and in China. And the CCP has long engaged in cyber espionage and hacking of U.S. academic medical centers and health care companies. In fact, PRC linked hackers have targeted American universities and firms in a bid to steal the IP related to coronavirus treatment and vaccines. Sometimes disrupting the work of our researchers. Having been caught covering up the coronavirus outbreak, Beijing is desperate for a public relations coup and may hope that it will be able to claim credit for any medical breakthroughs.

As all of these examples should make clear, the ultimate ambition of China's rulers isn't to trade with the United States, it is to raid the United States. If you are an American business leader, appeasing the PRC may bring short-term rewards, but in the end, the PRC's goal is to replace you. As a U.S. Chamber of Commerce report put it, the belief by foreign companies that large financial investments and sharing of expertise and significant technology transfers would lead to an ever opening China market is being replaced by boardroom banter that win-win in China means China wins twice.

Although Americans hope that trade and investment would liberalize China's political system, the fundamental character of the regime has never changed. As its ruthless crackdown of Hong Kong demonstrates once again, China is no closer to democracy today than it was in 1989 when tanks confronted pro-democracy protesters in Tiananmen Square. It remains an authoritarian one-party state in which the Chinese Communist Party wields absolute power unchecked by popular elections, the rule of law or an independent judiciary.

The CPP surveils its own people and assigns them social credit scores, employees an army of government censors, tortures dissidents and persecutes religious and ethnic minorities, including a million Uighurs detained in indoctrinate indoctrination and labor camps. If what happened in China stayed in China, that would be bad enough. But instead of America's changing China, China is leveraging its economic power to change America.

As this administration's China strategy recognizes, the CPC's campaign to compel ideological conformity does not stop at China's borders. Rather, the CCP seeks to extend its influence around the world including on American soil. All too often for the sake of short-term profits, American companies have succumbed to that influence, even at the expense of freedom and openness in the United States.

Sadly, examples of American business bowing to China art Legion. Take Hollywood. Hollywood's actors, producers, and directors pride themselves on celebrating freedom and the human spirit. And every year at the Academy Awards, Americans are lectured about how this country falls short of Hollywood's ideals of social justice. But Hollywood now regularly censors its own movies to appease the Chinese Communist Party, the world's most powerful violator of human rights.

This censorship infects not only the versions of movies that are released in China, but also many that are shown in the United States theaters to American audiences. For example, the hit movie World War Z depicts a zombie apocalypse caused by a virus. The original version of the film reportedly contained a scene with characters speculating that the virus may have originated in China. But the studio, Paramount Pictures reportedly told producers to delete the reference to China in the hope of landing a Chinese distribution deal. The deal never materialized.

In the Marvel Studios blockbuster Doctor Strange, film makers changed the nationality of the major character known as the Ancient One, a Tibetan monk in the comic book, changed it to from Tibetan to Celtic. When challenged about this, a screenwriter explained if you acknowledge that Tibet is a place and that he is Tibetan, you risk alienating 1 billion people. Or, as the Chinese government might say, we are not going to show your movie because you decided to get political.

These are just two examples of the many Hollywood films that have been altered one way or another to please the CCP. National Security Adviser O'Brien offered even more examples in his remarks. But many more scripts never see the light of day because writers and producers know not to test the limits. Chinese government censors don't need to say a word because Hollywood is doing their work for them. This is a massive propaganda coup for the Chinese Communist Party.

The story of the film industry's submission to the CCP is a familiar one. In the past two decades, China has emerged as the world's largest box office. That CCP has long tightly controlled access to that lucrative market both through quotas on American films imposed in violation of China's WTO obligations and a strict censorship regime. Increasingly, Hollywood also relies on Chinese money for financing.

In 2018, films with Chinese investors accounted for 20 percent of the U.S. box-office ticket sales compared to only 3 percent five years earlier. But in the long run, as with other Chinese industries, the PRC may be less interested in cooperating with Hollywood than in co-opting Hollywood and eventually replacing it with its own homegrown--homegrown movie productions.

To accomplish this, the CCP has been following its usual modus operandi. By imposing a quota on American films, the CCP pressures Hollywood studios to form joint ventures with Chinese companies who then gain U.S. technology and know-how. As one Chinese film executive recently put it, everything we've learned, we've learned from Hollywood. Notably in 2018--'19, 8 of the 10 top grossing films in China were produced in China.

Hollywood is far from alone in kowtowing to the PRC. America's big tech companies have also allowed themselves to become pawns of Chinese influence. In the year 2000 when the United States normalized trade relations with China, President Clinton hailed the new century as one in which Liberty will be spread by cell phone and cable modem. Instead, over the course of the next decade, American companies such as Cisco helped the Chinese communists build the great firewall of China, the world's most sophisticated system for Internet surveillance and censorship. Over the years, corporations such as Google, Microsoft, Yahoo, and Apple have shown themselves all too willing to collaborate with the CCP. For example, Apple recently removed the news app Quartz from its App Store in China after the Chinese government complained about the coverage of Hong Kong democracy protests.

Apple also removed the apps for virtual private networks, which had allowed users to circumvent the great firewall and illuminated pro-democracy songs from the Chinese music store. Meanwhile, the company announced that it would be transferring some of its iCloud data to servers in China, despite concerns that that move would give that Communist Party easier access to emails, text messages, and other user information stored in the iCloud.

Recently, we were able to get into two cell phones used by the Al-Qaeda terrorist who shot eight Americans at the Pensacola Naval Air Station. And during the gunfight with him, he stopped, disengaged, put his cell phones down and tried to destroy them shooting a bullet into one of his two cell phones. And we thought that suggested that there might be very important information about terrorist activities in those cell phones. And for four and a half months, we tried to get in without any help at all from Apple. Apple failed to give us any help getting into those cell phones.

We were ultimately able to get in through a fluke that we will not be able to reproduce in the future where we found communications with al Qaeda operatives in the Middle East up to the day before the attack. Do you think when Apple sells phones in China that Apple phones in China are impervious to penetration by Chinese authorities? They wouldn't be sold if they were impervious to Chinese authorities.

And what we've asked for is warrant--when we have a warrant from a court then we should be able to get into those cell phones. That's the double standard that has been emerging among American tech companies.

The CCP has long used public threats of retaliation and barred market--market access to exert influence. More recently, however, the CCP has also stepped up behind the scenes efforts to cultivate and coerce American business executives to further its political objectives. Efforts that are all the more pernicious because they are largely hidden from public view.

As China's government loses credibility around the world, the Justice Department has seen more and more PRC officials and their proxies reaching out to corporate leaders and inveighing them to favor policies and actions favored by the Chinese Communist Party. Their objective varies, but their pitch is generally the same. The businessperson has economic interest in China and there is a suggestion that things will go better or worse for them depending on their response to PRC's requests.

Privately pressuring and courting American corporate leaders to promote policies or you as politicians presents a significant threat because hiding behind American voices allows the Chinese government to elevate its influence campaigns and put a friendly face on its pro regime policies. The legislator or the policy maker who hears from these American businessmen is probably more sympathetic to that constituent than to a foreigner. And by masking its participation in our political process, the PRC avoids accountability for its influence efforts and the public outcry that might result if its lobbying are exposed.

America's corporate leaders might not think of themselves as lobbyists. You might think, for example, that cultivating a mutually beneficial relationship is just part of a--of Guanxi, a system of influence--influential social networking necessary to do business in the PRC. But you should be alert to how you might be used and how your efforts on behalf of a foreign company or government could implicate the Foreign Agents Registration Act.

FARA does not prohibit any speech or conduct, but it does require those who are acting as agents of foreign principals to publicly in disclose that relationship and their political or other similar activities by registering with the Justice Department, allowing the audience to take into account the origin of the speech when evaluating credibility. By focusing on American business leaders, I don't mean to suggest that they are the only targets of Chinese influence operations, but they are principled targets today of Chinese influence operations in the United States.

The Chinese Communist Party also seeks to infiltrate, sensor, or co-opt American academic and research institutions. For example, dozens of American universities host Chinese government funded Confucian institutes, which have been accused of pressuring host universities to silence discussion or cancel events on topics considered controversial by Beijing. Universities must stand up for each other, refused to let the CCP dictate research efforts or suppress diverse voices, support colleagues and students who wish to speak their minds, and consider whether any sacrifice of academic integrity or freedom is worth the price of a appeasing the CCP's demands.

In a globalized world, American corporations and universities alike may view themselves as global citizens rather than as American institutions, but they should remember that what allowed them to succeed in the first place was the American free enterprise system, that rule of law, and the security of afforded by America's economic technological and military strength. Globalization does not always point in the direction of greater freedom.

A world marching to the beat of the communist China's--Chinese drum will not be hospitable be a hospitable one for institutions that depend on free markets, free trade, or the free exchange of ideas. There was a time when American companies understood that they saw them--understood this and they saw themselves as American and proudly defended American values.

In World War II, for example, the iconic American company Disney made dozens of public information films about for the government, including training videos to educate American sailors on navigation tactics. During the war, over at 90 percent of Disney's employees were devoted to the production of training and public information films. To boost the morale of America's troops, at Disney also designed Insignia that appeared in planes, trucks, flight jackets, and other military equipment used by American allied forces.

I suspect that Walt Disney would be disheartened to see how the company he founded deals with foreign dictatorships today. When Disney produced Kundun, the 1997 film about the PRC's oppression of the Dalai Lama, the CCP objected to the project and pressured Disney to abandon it, ultimately, Disney decided that it couldn't let a foreign power dictate whether it would distribute a movie in the United States. But that moment of courage wouldn't last.

After that CCP banned all Disney films in China, the company lobbied hard to regain access and the CEO apologized for Kundun, calling it a stupid mistake. Disney then Began courting the PRC to open a 5.5 billion theme park in Shanghai. As part of that deal, Disney agreed to give the Chinese government officials role in its management. Of the parks full time employees, 300 are active members of the Communist Party and they reportedly display hammer and sickle insignia on their desks and attend party lectures at the facility during business hours.

Like other American companies, Disney may eventually learn the hard way the cost of compromising its principles. Soon after Disney opened its park in Shanghai, a Chinese owned theme park popped up a couple 100 miles away featuring characters that, according to news reports looked suspiciously like Snow White and other Disney trademarks. Americas--American companies must understand the stakes. The Chinese Communist Party thinks in terms of decades and centuries, but we tend to focus on the next quarter's earnings report.

But if Disney and other American corporations continue to bow to Beijing, they risk undermining both their own future, competitiveness, and prosperity as well as that classical liberal order that has allowed them to thrive. During the Cold War, Lewis Powell, later Justice Powell sent an important memorandum to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. He noted that the free enterprise system was under unprecedented attack and urged American companies to do more to preserve it.

The time has come, he said, indeed it is long overdue for the wisdom, ingenuity, and resources of American business to be marshaled against those who would destroy it. So too today. The American people are more attuned than ever to the threat that the Chinese Communist Party poses not only to our way of life, but to our very lives and livelihoods and they will increasingly call out corporate appeasement.

If individual companies are afraid to take a stand, there is strength in numbers. As a Justice Powell wrote, strength lies in organization and careful long range planning and implementation, in consistency of action over an indefinite period of years, in the scale of financing available only through joint efforts and in the political power available only through united action and national organization.

Despite years of acquiescence in communist authorities in China, America's tech companies may finally be finding their courage through collective action. Following the recent imposition of the PRC's draconian national security law in Hong Kong, many big tech companies, including Facebook, Google, Twitter, Zoom, and LinkedIn reportedly announced that they would temporarily suspend compliance with government requests for user data.

True to form, communist officials have threatened imprisonment for non-compliant company employees. We will see if these companies hold firm and how long they hold firm. We hope they do. If they stand together, they will provide a worthy example for other American companies in resisting the Chinese Communist Party's corrupt and dictatorial rule.

The CCP has launched an orchestrated campaign across all of its many tentacles in Chinese government and society to exploit the openness of our institutions in order to destroy them. To secure a world of freedom and prosperity for our children and our grandchildren, the free world will need its own version of a whole of society approach in which the public and private sectors maintain their separation but work together collaboratively to resist domination and to win the contest for the commanding heights of the global economy.

America has done that before and if we rekindle our love and devotion of our country and each other, I am confident that we, the American people, the American government and American business together can do it again. Our freedom depends on it. Thank you very much.

(APPLAUSE)

Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. Thank you, very much.

urn:contentItem:5XR0-4F21-F15W-H02B-00000-00Attorney General Barr Participates in a Discussion at the Wall Street Journal CEO Council2019-12-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:28ZLexisNexisAttorney General Barr Participates in a Discussion at the Wall Street Journal CEO Council

Attorney General Barr Delivers Remarks On Antitrust Issues

December 10, 2019 01:15 P.M.

SPEAKERS:

WALL STREET JOURNAL EDITOR AT LARGE JERRY BAKER

ATTORNEY GENERAL WILLIAM P. BARR

[*](APPLAUSE)

BAKER: Thank you very much, indeed, John for that introduction. Thank you, General Barr, for being here. Welcome.

BARR: Thanks.

BAKER: The headline for this--

(AUDIO GAP)

--and with your indulgence, there's quite a lot of news, as John said, at the moment. So I'm going to start with the other matters part of the--

(LAUGHTER)

BARR: Sure, that would be (INAUDIBLE).

BAKER: --the other matters part of the program. So you may--it may possibly have captured your attention this morning that the House of Representatives published two articles of impeachment against the president of the United States. Let me just read out an excerpt from the first article of impeachment, which says that using the pow--using the powers of his high office, President Trump solicited the interference of a foreign government, Ukraine, in the 2020 U.S. presidential election. He solicited the government of Ukraine to announce investigations that would, among other things, harm the election prospects of a political opponent. Is that not exactly the sort of abuse of power that the founders had in mind when they drew up the impeachment clause of the Constitution?

BARR: You put so much work into that question. I feel--

(LAUGHTER)

--I feel bad that I'm going to give you the answer (INAUDIBLE)

BAKER: I had all morning, after all.

(LAUGHTER)

BARR: Which is, you know, there's this political constitutional process underway on the Hill, and the attorney general is not part of that process, and at this stage I'm just not going to comment on it.

BAKER: Nothing at all?

BARR: I will say--I will say that on the other article of impeachment relating to obstruction, I don't believe it's the case that where somebody, including a branch of government, is asserting a legal privilege that they have under the law, that that constitutes obstruction.

BAKER: The second article says President Trump directed the unprecedented categorical and indiscriminate defiance of subpoenas issued by the House of Representatives and under--given that the Constitution gives the House sole responsibility for impeachment, this is itself a--represents obstruction.

BARR: As I said, I just said what I said, which is it was predicated on advancing claims of privilege that have been previously advanced in other administrations, and I don't consider that obstruction.

BAKER: So it is not unprecedented?

BARR: No.

BAKER: Let's move on to the other issue that was occupying a lot of your attention yesterday, which was the publication of the report of the Justice Department's Inspector General Michael Horowitz into the origins of the--and the conduct of the investigation of President Trump and his associates around the Russia allegations about collusion with Russia.

Mr. Horowitz in his report said yesterday, we concluded that the FBI had an authorized purpose when it opened Crossfire Hurricane--that was the name of the--given to the investigation--to obtain information about or protect against a national security threat or federal crime. You said in response to that yesterday, the FBI launched an intrusive investigation on the thinnest of suspicions that were in my view insufficient to justify the steps taken. Could you tell us what exactly it is--where exactly you disagree with Mr. Horowitz?

BARR: Okay. Well, first let me say I think there are sort of three parts or issues--well, let's say categories of--of analysis in the report. The first is was the investigation adequately predicated, start of it? The second one is how was it conducted? And I break that down into two things, how was it conducted before the election and how was it conducted after the election? The real meat of Horowitz's work and the real thrust of the report actually deals with the conduct of the investigation, where I think it quickly became apparent that it was a travesty. And there were many abuses. And that's by far the most important part of the report. I think Mike Horowitz would agree with that.

BAKER: The abuses, these--I want to come onto these in detail, but abuses that in particular refer to the FISA application--the application to the FI--for the--

BARR: And also the--and also the fact that from day one it generated exculpatory information and nothing that substantiated any kind of collusion. But that aside from it and going back to the issue, in many ways sort of the issue of whether it technically was adequately predicated is something of academic interest only, but where I disagree--and by the way, Mike knows I disagree with him, and there are still people in this town where you can have--where, you know, you can be adults and professionals and have disagreement without tearing each other's hearts out. So it's just one of those things. We have disagreements in the Department of Justice.

But I think that the basic--it's a big deal to use the law enforcement and the intelligence resources of the United States government to investigate a campaign of, especially an opposing party. I can't think of an--I'm sure there were instances in the past, but I can't think of any recent instance where that was done.

BAKER: The report does make clear there were concerns about that and discussions at very high levels within the FBI as to the sensitive information, sensitive (INAUDIBLE)

BARR: And so, you know, basically the department, as you would expect, the principles are essentially rule of reason. What is the basis you have for looking into something, and, you know, what are reasonable steps to take? Taking into consideration the weight of the evidence that's prompting you to do that, the alternatives available and exactly what you are trying to accomplish and also the sensitivity of the area involved here, a political campaign, core First Amendment activity. And where I disagree with Mike is I just think this was very flimsy. This was a comment made by a 28-year-old volunteer in a campaign in a bar, offhand, which was described as a suggestion of a suggestion.

BAKER: Right.

BARR: And I personally think the subject matter of it, which was the fact, you know, some vague allusion to the fact that the Russians may have something that they could dump. At that time, in May 2016, there was rampant speculation going on in the media on the blogosphere and in political circles that Hillary Clinton's email server had in 2014 been hacked and therefore the Russians might have those emails. So drawing the conclusion that this kind of vague comment related to and showed pre-knowledge of the DNC hack and dump, I think was a big stretch. But let me just finalize it, which is from my experience the normal thing to do in this kind of situation--and I have had analogous experience here--is to go--to go to the--to go to the campaign, and here I don't think there is a legitimate explanation for why they didn't, especially because they went to the Russians.

BAKER: Well I think actually in the report I think it does say that, you know, they considered this, but there were concerns that because the campaign--they would be alerting the campaign if there was criminal activity going on they would be alerting the campaign and they would be able to shut it down.

BARR: Right, and what the FBI person said as to why he didn't is he said we only do that if we're--if we are certain, if there is no possibility whatever that the person is witting of their--and that's simply not true. I mean, I have authorized defensive briefings, and I know of defensive briefings that are regularly conducted. You look at all the circumstances. If your purpose was to protect the election, then you would've done a defensive briefing here because the chances of people like Sessions or Chris Christie being in cahoots with the Russians were pretty minimal, but if there was stuff going on, then by going in you brace them and you disrupt the activity in time to protect the election.

But it just doesn't hold water because on August 4 they contacted the head of Russia intelligence and said we know what you're up to; you better stop it. They did again in later August, and President Obama did it directly in September. So it doesn't strike me as plausible that you would tell the Russians who clearly were guilty of interference, but you wouldn't--wouldn't go and talk to the campaign. That makes no sense.

BAKER: So you believe the predicate was very, very flimsy.

BARR: Yeah.

BAKER: Essentially, you've just laid that out. So why did they do it? Do you think there was some political motivation on the part of people at the FBI to--or the Justice Department to the FBI at the time to go off of the Trump campaign this way?

BARR: That's why we have Durham. I mean, Durham--Durham, you know, was able to look at all the evidence. He's able to not only look at the evidence within the FBI, he's able to require people to testify. He's--

BAKER: This is the U.S. attorney (INAUDIBLE).

BARR: U.S. attorney, and--and he's able to talk to other agencies, he is able to talk to private parties. There is a lot of swirling activity going on at this time, it wasn't all in the FBI, so I think he will have a broader appreciation of all of the facts and a determination can be made. I don't know what the motivations were, and I am not--I am not saying they were improper motivations but I--I think it is premature to you know rule definitively there wasn't. Now in that regard, people have to understand the role of the IG. You know we are an agency that makes discretionary decisions every day, thousands of them and the internal watchdog, his general approach and it is the right approach and I respect it is--is to say look, if the people involved give me reasonable explanations for what they do that is there--their explanation is not unreasonable on their face and I can't find in the documentary or testimonial evidence that contradicts it I will accept it and that is what happened here.

He said I haven't found evidence of improper motive. He did not--contrary to what a lot of media is reporting he did not find there was no improper motive, he didn't find evidence of improper motive.

BAKER: The evidence of absence of evidence is not (INAUDIBLE). So Christopher Wray, the FBI director similarly said yesterday in response to the report the--the report did not find, we did not find believable bias or improper motivation. Again do--do you challenge that?

BARR: No, I am just saying what--what the IG found, the IG said I didn't--I didn't--did not find documentary or testimonial evidence contradicting the reason or the explanations that were given to me and I excepted them. He--he is not definitively ruling that there was no bias. I think that is why we have Durham.

BAKER: The initial investigation the FBI again in the report it says the FBI saw that and (INAUDIBLE) refer to that initial conversation between George Papadopoulos and Alexander Downer it is just referred to in the report as--I love these acronyms, FFG, friendly foreign government.

BARR: Friendly foreign government (INAUDIBLE).

BAKER: FFG.

BARR: We never heard (INAUDIBLE) or not.

BAKER: We also have CHS, confidential human sources and various others but--but there was this conversation between Papadopoulos and the Australian which probably wasn't reported actually for about two months I think after the initial--after the initial conversation but the FBI regarded that as a tipping point given what had been seen about the WikiLeaks publication, what it knew about the DNC hack already and that this some--is it not reasonable that they thought given that they knew there was this extensive Russian effort to intervene in the election along comes somebody inside the Trump campaign who says you know what we've got this information and possibly I have been offered--I have been offered information possibly dirt on Hillary Clinton is that not reasonable then for the FBI to go ahead and say you know what we probably need to investigate this?

BARR: That is why I sort of expanded on this say little bit in the front and. The basic official version is that we thought the Russians were hacking into the DNC, and on July 23, WikiLeaks dumped DNC emails. Then a foreign official comes in and says you know, back in May this guy said something in and it bothered me, it was a suggestion than a suggestion and before they even interviewed that person they--the open the counterintelligence investigation on the whole campaign on the idea that this must reflect pre-knowledge of the hack.

I am saying that when you actually look at the surrounding circumstances, that was--that was a bridge too far. I mean there--it wasn't reasonable for them to assume that and the proper response was to talk to the campaign. That is normally where it would happen. You know this happens all of the time in campaigns. You know distraught foreign donors, through scrub donors and there is hanky-panky going on and usually, we don't assume it is the government that the campaign is part of that plot. We go and we say to the campaign hey, there's foreign people that are feeding money into your campaign and so forth. So the idea that you only talk to the--some of Americans involved here if you are 100 percent certain that they are not culpable is simply not true.

BAKER: Just very quickly on this because we do want to move on to other things, but on the FISA application, particularly again, the report is very critical. Documents 17 omissions or errors in the--on the initial or the three subsequent applications to the FISA court for surveillance of (INAUDIBLE) as we know that the report does say it resulted in FISA applications that made it appear that the information supporting probable cause was stronger than was actually the case. Do you think that, given that that actually those FISA applications should never have been made?

BARR: Yes, the--this is the meat of the issue, and if you actually spend time to look what happened, I think you would be appalled. Remember they say okay, we are not going to go and talk to the campaign. We are going to send people in and wire them up and have them talk to the individuals. That happened. That happened in August, September and October, and it all came back exculpatory people saying I don't know--don't know what you are talking about. Not only exculpatory as to the relationship with the Russians but as to the specific facts and that day they never did anything about that. They just pressed ahead but be, they never informed the court. They were told they didn't have probable cause to get a warrant and so they took the steel dossier, which they had done nothing to verify, and they use that to get the warrant, collapse everything. They--they withheld from the court all of the exculpatory information and they withheld from the court information about the lack of reliability of Steele.

The real interesting thing here, to me the major take go away actually is after the election because in January they went to--Steele was dealing with one person, only talk to one person, and that is the--what we call the primary sub source and it was that person who have the so-called network of sub-sources. When they finally got around to talking to him he said I don't know what Steele is talking about, I didn't tell him this stuff or you know it was mostly barroom talk and rumor. I made it clear to him this was my own suppositions and theories and you know this--and at that point, it was clear that the dossier was a sham. So what happens? What happens at that point? They don't tell the court and they continue to get FISA warrants based on that dossier and more damning is that they actually filed with a court a statement saying we talked to the sub source and we found him credible and cooperative and they put that into bolster--

BAKER: When the sub source (INAUDIBLE)--

BARR: What he was being truthful about is that the dossier was garbage. So it is hard to look at this stuff. I think that it was a gross abuse.

BAKER: Let me put it another way. Do you think the judges, the four separate FISA judges in those courts were badly misled?

BARR: Yes.

BAKER: Just final question on this. The report also says this was a failure not only of the operational team in the FBI but if the managers and supervisors including senior officials in the chain of command there's going to--there's going--are people going to be held accountable?

BARR: Well, they are all gone.

BAKER: Do they need to be held? Is there some--you have mentioned--you have mentioned obviously the other investigations going on?

BARR: You know, I think that's--that's--

BAKER: Is that up to and including Jim Comey, Andrew McCabe?

BARR: I am not going to speculate who but

BAKER: Do you think they--do you think they are implicated in that statement?

BARR: I think I have said that I think that group there was a failure of leadership, and I will just quote the IG, and the IG says that the explanations he received were not satisfactory. When you have the kind of rank behavior that man involved and the IG says he doesn't get an explanation for it you can draw your own conclusions from that but here--here I want to say one of the things that is poisonous about our politics is the use of the criminal law process as a political weapon and both sides to some extent are guilty of this and instead of just invading ideas may want to label their adversary as a criminal and they you know for over the U.S. code to try to find some kind of esoteric argument as to why won't when someone does there is a crime, and you get into criminal investigation. And then they start calling for scouts. So you know nowadays I am constantly hit why aren't people going to prison for what they did to the president. On the other side, you know throw Bill Barr in prison and these things take time.

(LAUGHTER)

You know at the end of the day we are all protected by the fact and this is something I will get to if you want to talk about white-collar crime--

BAKER: Yes, I do.

BARR: Which is--

BAKER: (INAUDIBLE) nothing but white-collar crime I think you were talking about a different (INAUDIBLE).

BARR: What protects all of us is that the government has to have proof beyond a reasonable doubt at least under Justice Department standards before we indict anybody and that is a pretty substantial hurdle, and no one is going to go to jail and no one is going to be indicted unless that standard is men and I know a lot of people (INAUDIBLE) they think if I don't like someone and I don't like what they did and I am morally outraged send them to jail and why isn't this person being indicted and that is you know sort of poisoning the system. And that's you know, sort of poisoning the system.

BAKER: Very quick question before you get onto that address. On--on the Ukraine issue--famous July 25th phone call between President Trump and President Zelensky which is the cause of this impeachment proceeding that we are seeing today. There is--there is a quote in there where he says there is a lot of--President Trump says to President Zelensky there is a lot of talk about Biden's son. That Biden stopped the prosecution that was of the--of the Ukrainian prosecutor and a lot of people want to find out about that. So, whatever you can do with the Attorney General that would be great. It seems horrible to me.

Did the Ukrainians do anything with you?

BARR: No.

BAKER: Nothing at all?

BARR: No. That is taken out of context just to be fair. I mean, in the president's call he started out by talking about the abuses in the 2016 election that he said our country has paid a heavy price for and he asked them to work with the Attorney General on that.

Now, the fact is I was smart enough not to get involved with Ukraine. At least put it very low on the list.

BAKER: You can trust yourself--trust yourself with Rudy Giuliani you are saying?

BARR: I am saying that you know, that hadn't reached the top of my to do list yet and so fortunately I hadn't you know, looked into the Ukraine situation. But he then later in the conversation gets into other things and then he starts throwing different names around.

But the fact, as I said at the time I had no dealings with Ukraine. I had no dealings with Rudy Giuliani about Ukraine.

BAKER: Just raise the question, why was this never a U.S. investigation? The allegation was that a U.S. citizen was perhaps corruptly acting you know with a--with a Ukrainian--why was all the pressure on the Ukrainians to announce an investigation? Why was--why would then--why would that not be a matter for U.S. investigatorial authorities?

BARR: You know, I at the time I--I don't know whether it was or not frankly.

BAKER: Antitrust. The--it has been widely reported. I know you can't talk about it the Justice Department the antitrust division is investigating big tech--technology--technology firms I know you had a strong interest in this--in this over the years. But in the private sector now in your role big investigation meanwhile the FTC is also--also investigation.

There seems to be (INAUDIBLE) supporting Washington to do something about what is seen as the dominating position of big tech again, I don't even want to talk about the details. But first can I just ask you the timing on that investigation? Are you, it was announced over the summer are you expecting any kind of eminent resolution? Can we expect it sometime next year?

BARR: You know, I don't want to sort of predict that. I started it in Ju--we started in earnest in July. It has been moving very quickly. We have a very--ambitious schedule and things are--are keeping up to schedule. We are talking very broadly with people, getting a lot of input from people int eh industry and experts and so forth and we are doing our analysis. And, you know, I would like to have it completed sometime next year.

I think it's important to move quickly on things. That is something we can talk about later. You know, these things have cost to the marketplace and to the businesses. And I think at some point the government has to fish or cut bait.

BAKER: What are the principals here at stake? I mean obviously, bigness alone is not these are enormous companies. They dominate sectors. They dominate the U.S. economy and the markets in this way. But it is well established that scale alone is not sufficient to warrant antitrust enforcement action or even to raise necessarily concerns about--about--about unfair behavior.

So what--what--what would be the pr--without getting into it again, what are the concerns about what Google, Facebook, Amazon, Apple, maybe others are doing?

BARR: Let me just say you know, our--our review is not just limited to antitrust. Antitrust obviously is front and center but there are also other concerns relating to these companies. Other laws might apply to. There is some pressure or some people have suggested sort of strong arming the antitrust laws in order to reach things that really were not intended to be covered by the antitrust laws. And I am not really in line with that. I don't mind updating making sure that we are properly applying the antitrust laws to new situations.

But we are looking at antitrust. We are also looking at behavior across the board and how it implicates other laws. The problem obviously, and I said this in my confirmation hearing you know, big is not bad. I work for Verizon and I really appreciate that. But the question is when you have the kind of market power that some companies have in their--in their market then some conduct which you may--which may have made sense when they were sort of the insurgent company in a growing industry can become anticompetitive because it ends up fortifying the monopoly.

So, there is conduct that has grown up in these businesses that we have to take a look at and see the extent to which it really involves maintaining a--maintaining a monopoly. Also, this is particularly true where you have a powerful network effects like you do in these sectors. The other thing is that these are businesses that operate in multiple submarkets and you have to do a lot of thinking about how--how they potentially are leveraging power one and to another and also the role that data plays in that.

BAKER: Couple--couple of the issues again. You got you may or may not want to comment on it. But couple of things that people have raised concerns about are things like, for example, bias in search results. That they could be the algorithms could possibly, conceivably be favoring either their own products or people who paid whatever. Is that--is that--is that a possibility? Is that something you are looking into?

BARR: Well, I can say exactly what we are looking into. I think Google has made public that they received civil investigative demands. I think it is apparent to every kinds of practices that are potentially (INAUDIBLE) could be one.

BAKER: What about the simple scale of online advertising--Facebook and Google dominate online advertising. Is that, in itself, the scale that they have is that a source of concern of potential antitrust action?

BARR: that goes to the market power and then you have to look at particular practices that may essentially exclude other competitors and--and lock in their market power. As I said successfully competing and getting into a dominant position is not itself, wrong.

BAKER: What about the use of these--there is an intriguing article by the way, the Wall Street Journal just published today that said that points out that while Facebook and Google may defend themselves on the grounds that they are not--they are not raising prices it is all they provide is free and actually they provide a tremendous benefit.

There is an interesting new argument I think in antitrust that actually what they are doing in a sense, they are charging consumers by using their--by using their data. And that--that is if you like a--a cost to the consumer a non-monetary cost perhaps, but a cost to the consumer that their data is being used and that itself could represent exploitation of a monopoly in a way that is unhealthy and potentially in breach of antitrust.

Is that an argument, is that a theory that you are open to?

BARR: I'm--I'm inclined to think that there is no free lunch and something that is free is actually getting paid for one way or another. So, I am open to that argument.

BAKER: Could one solution--one solution there be that maybe people suggested that people should be paying that I am happy to for--for Facebook to use my data but it has a value and I should be--I should be--I should receive compensation for it?

BARR: I don't want to start talking about potential policy responses. You know, there--you know, I think the--the public interest, consumer interest standard is broad enough to--to reach not just issues of pricing but wholesale practices relating to free--so called freebies, but as you--as you said at the beginning one of the interesting things about this issue is the bipartisan support for the issue.

I found that out, going around it was the only thing that some people were civil to me about during my confirmation. But we have 50--

BAKER: You and Elizabeth Warren are on exactly the same page.

BARR: Ah.

(LAUGHTER)

But 50 state AGs have now coalesced that we are working with all 50 state AGs. Now for those of you who have had companies dealing with state AGs and coalitions of state AGs you know, it is a pretty difficult situation when you are in a business. But there is--there is compete consensus that something should be done and we are trying to work closely with them.

One you know, if there is a basis for the litigation, if there is a basis for other enforcement action so be it. But there also may be an opportunity for legislative proposals.

BAKER: One more quick question on--on the tech which is encryption. I know there has been again, some consideration of this and I think your deputy made clear recently this is part of the litigation. This issue of seeing end to end encryption is very, very hard--obviously, it is designed that way--very, very hard for anybody to crack. And it does have law enforcement implications.

Is that something you're looking you--you--you think needs to you have already whether it is with WhatsApp or Facebook Messenger is that something you want to--to address?

BARR: I mean, that's one of our highest priorities. It's something I've talked about a lot. You know, basically we are not concerned about the kind of encrypt--you know, encryption is good in that it enables, you know, the commercial use of the Internet. We're not talking about encryption, you know, in dealing with your bank or a vendor or something like that because the government, with a warrant, can go and get the information needs from the vendor or the bank.

What we're talking about is consumer products that provide into in encryption like WhatsApp and Signal and other things. Criminal organizations, and I'm talking about terrorist organizations, drug cartels, child molesting rings and, you know, kiddie porn type ring, are moving to encryption--encrypted end-to-end apps which completely defeats the ability of the government to get in there.

So, we have--we--we have increasing number of horror stories about how people are dying or being molested or whatever that we cannot get into. We know it's happening but we can't get into the communications. This also goes to telephones. We can pick up a terrorist telephone and not be able to get into it. Fortunately, sometimes we can get into it but not all the time.

And, you know, we're talking, by the way, about no diminution in privacy. What we're talking about is when you actually have a warrant based on probable cause that a crime is being committed, you cannot get the information. And I sort of sum up the whole thing this way. These businesses are essentially selling this. They're basically saying to people, hey, we can give you the protection against any scrutiny from the government whatsoever. No matter what you do, you are completely impervious to government surveillance.

That might sound good to the individual, but do we want to live in a society like that were everybody is absolutely insulated from any government scrutiny even when there's probable cause to believe a crime is underway? I don't think we do. So--

BAKER: One more question on antitrust. A feature of U.S. economy in the last 25 years has been a dramatic increase in concentration in sector after sector, the number of mergers and acquisitions, companies going under. There's been a--you know, a recent survey said that I think 75 percent of U.S. industries had seen a significant increase in concentration from five to four companies or four to three companies. And there's tons of evidence that this is not--this is harming the consumer.

You look at things like broadband, for example, a very good example. You know quite a lot about this, I'm sure. There--you know, there were two or three major companies providing broadband services, two or three major companies providing cell phone services. There's a very interesting new book out by an economist at New York University which estimates that--that--that the prices in these areas, costs to the consumer in these areas, in the sectors of the economy where there is--there is this concentration is significant. And he compares U.S. concentration and U.S. prices to Europe, to prices in Europe.

We don't think of Europe as a particularly competitive market particularly. But, for example, broadband--average price of broadband in the United States is $68 a month. In France, it's $31 a month. And it's only $30 a month. Cell phone use, U.S. $100 a month; EU it's about half that. Whether--whether you dispute the figures are not, there has been this dramatic concentration of sector after sector, with plenty of evidence that it's--that it's harming the consumer. Do you think there needs to be a fundamental review, either through antitrust--obviously, antitrust would be an obvious way to do it, but somewhere else of actually examining these and restoring some degree of competitive pressure to many of the sectors?

BARR: No.

BAKER: Just not--you don't think it's a problem?

BARR: I think you--I think it--

BAKER: --You don't--

BARR: --I don't think you can make that kind of general statement across all business and all sectors. I think it's a sector by sector market by market analysis to see--you know, to assess concentration. I think some markets actually benefit from concentration--some degree of concentration.

BAKER: Which markets? Yeah.

BARR: Telecom. No, I mean--

BAKER: --Well, maybe the--maybe the companies benefit, but from what--

BARR: --I think that--I think the American--

BAKER: --At least the--the consumers don't see it.

BARR: I think--I think in certain network industries, you can just--you can--you can be too Balkanized and know what has the scale necessary for the kind of innovation that we're seeing. And also, I think it's sometimes hard to assess technological change. So, you know, 5G sort of changes the--the whole idea of broadband availability and so forth.

You know, I--I think you have to look at it sector by sector with an appreciation of technology. You know, I think back when I was at Verizon, people were still, you know, looking at it as--you know, they wanted to, you know, increase the number of competitors on telephone by essentially converting the local phone companies into wholesale platforms, and everyone else glommed onto it at discounted prices.

And the regulators were, you know, spending all their time on that. Meanwhile, what happens? What happens is IP protocol on cable, which then immediately turned the cable companies into competitors. So--and--and now we have, you know, wireless and so forth. So, I think it's a sector by sector, market by market analysis, anything some markets benefit from a few--a few players. Some may, you know, require more.

BAKER: A quick couple of final questions. We're running out of time. You came--you were--you were attorney general 20--almost 30 years ago, 25 years ago the first time around in the first Bush administration when you were what, 15--15 years old, something like that? Yeah.

BARR: Forty-one, yeah.

BAKER: You're back this time.

BARR: Let me just tell you that I have a--in my view on this thing is that there's only--the only people who should be attorney general are people who are too young to know the risk or too old to care.

(LAUGHTER)

BAKER: Well, we'll--we won't--we won't decide which--which--which category you're in, but just what's your--I know you worked in the private sector, you've talked about it a little bit, for most of that interim period. As you come back in to the--you've obviously been somewhat hit by all these--all these impeachment and other related issues and investigations and everything else.

But as--from the point of view of business, what you've seen from outside the--the Justice Department, from outside government in the last 20 years or so, what--what--what do you want to do--and you've doubtless had to deal with the Justice Department in--in--in various roles in many ways. What do you want to do? What--what needs to be done, do you think, to--for--especially from the perspective of this business audience, to make that experience in dealing with law enforcement fairer, more effective, maybe more transparent? What--what--

BARR: --Yeah--

BAKER: --What are your priorities there?

BARR: So, my view is you shouldn't work in a senior position in the Department of Justice unless you--unless you've spent a lot of your time on the outside dealing with the Department of Justice, so a--a number of things. Number one, time. I think there's a risk of the department and other--other agencies, you know, they think they can take forever on the--their matters. And they do, and they come in, you know, sort of like day after day in the case, or the--it's like a--their rice bowl for the next five years is investigation.

My attitude is fish or cut bait. The government--that has huge cost of the government in terms of opportunity cost for you to be, excuse the expression, dicking around with some case that really isn't getting anywhere, and it's very costly to the--to the private sector to be under this kind of cloud. So, I want to make sure that people purposefully address a case, and there's a someone who sensible them up and say is this going to get anywhere? At the end of the day, are we going to be able to prove a crime beyond a reasonable doubt? And if we're not going to be in that position and it's a disproportionate amount, are we going to move on to the next thing? So, I'm impatient with, you know, sort of the backlog of cases and the time--the average life of cases.

An--another issue is, you know, esoteric legal theories. You know, enforce the law in the core meat and potatoes area where the law is supposed to apply. And they'll come in here with some kind of esoteric application of the law just because you can catch the company. The other thing is, you know, let's face it, companies are like shooting fish in a barrel. Very few companies are going to go and take the risk of a trial.

And so, over the years, a state of mind has--has arisen where, you know, you get the company over a barrel, you just get--you know, it's a question of how much money you're going to get. So, we've adopted the policy that, in order to come in to resolve the case, the prosecutors have to come in with a trial plan. They have to show that they can establish beyond a reasonable doubt all the elements of a crime and the--and what witnesses they are going to be able to call to do that. They're going to show they have to do the work to say that we can prove beyond a reasonable doubt that this company is guilty.

Now, if a company rushes in, you know, the day after their caught and says, hey, we want a DPA and, you know, we're willing to pay anything, I'm not saying that we wait until we develop the case, okay? You want to deal, we'll deal. But if--if a company is being held up on something that's unjust, we want to put the prosecutors through the ringer, that they actually have to have the evidence and be able to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that this is not an extortion of the company. Those are some of the ways that I--I'm trying to address it.

Now, there's a lot going on, and I can't give this my undivided attention. But--but, you know, this is one of the reforms I'd like to see.

BAKER: Final question. You gave a speech a few weeks ago which attracted a lot of attention at the University of Notre DameLaw School--

BARR: --Um-hmm--

BAKER: --In which you talked about the centrality of religious liberty in the United States, and its history and the mind of the fine--founding fathers and those traditional religious--religious values and how much--how important they are to a fully functioning free democracy actually said the traditional religious values are under threat now--are the target of organized destruction you said. So attacking traditional religious values whether it's over requiring catholic institutions to--to provide contraception to their employees or the LGBT rights to others people organizations that maybe disagree with--don't accept those.

Now, this attracted a lot of attention to people on the left got a lot of criticism from liberals. The New Yorker actually called it the worst speech by an Attorney General in modern history. You must some badge--badge of pride for that bit there.

But could you just give us just the--the final--it's a final--final moments a little bit more about what that is --why--why you think religious freedom is under threat and why it's--what you particularly as the Attorney General of the United States perhaps can do to defend it and to restore it to its central role in the U.S. and the U.S. Constitution--U.S. life?

BARR: Legally speaking there used to be a consensus there was a you know, just 10 years ago, 15 years ago that there should be an accommodation of religion. In fact, that passed overwhelmingly in congress and you know, Chuck Schumer was the cosponsor of it.

And, I think Teddy Kennedy and Hatch were involved. Which is, you know, maximum accommodation to religion. Religion is a good thing and we may have a general rule but if it steps on somebody's toes we try to accommodate it that's gone by the boards.

Now, we almost people--some people seem to take light enforcing particular groups to accept something that is an (INAUDIBLE) to them. You know, I think hu--humans have lived with religion for 500--evolved with religion for 50,000 years. I think it regardless and I am not saying it is just a utilitarian thing but--but it has been a very important part of--of our ability to live together in a community and--and our founders believed that they can provide the kind of freedom that they did in this system precisely because they felt that the moral values that people had pr--primarily from religion they would be able to control themselves.

So, we can give the maximum freedom and that if--if they don't have that then society become smore and more tyrannical and starts making all the rules. And, I feel that there has been a breakdown of self-control and that the government is performing the role of sort of the alleviator of the consequences that essentially subsidizing irresponsibility and misconduct so we are getting more and more of it, less and less self-control.

And, you know, government is--you know, facilitating that and I think we would be better off to take a more neutral and more accommodating opposition toward religion--not opposition hostility toward religion. I think you know, the Constitution has been misinterpreted too.

BAKER: This is a (INAUDIBLE) we had a session this morning Chief Executives are increasingly you know, demanded to take public stances on some of these issues in ways that a lot of religious people object to. Is that some--is that--is that a threat again, to the religious freedom values that you are talking about?

BARR: What--what do you mean?

BAKER: For example, they are--are--are strongly under pressure in all of these issues of social, social concern whether it be again, LGBT rights for example, some people may object to those. They may find it very difficult to have that you know a--a religious view which is consistent to what you--but you think--but it does seem like the prevailing atmosphere these days requires chief executives to embrace rights that may be--and we have seen some of these religious (INAUDIBLE) come along with you know, the stuff that sort of Chick-fil-A is going through or some of these other issues. We are seeing you know, more and more pressure on companies. You know, some people regard it as a good thing. What is your view?

BARR: My view is you know I--I--I don't think it's a good development to have you know, all these social warriors you know, essentially pushing companies to take positions on these kinds of things. Those are the companies that do it's fine. That's their choice and if the shareholders are happy that's fine too.

But what I was saying is and I think I said this at my confirmation you know, it is one thing--I personally do not believe that gay people should be discriminated against in work. That's not currently in our law but I have no problem with that. I think that's the right thing. But on the other hand I think there has to be accommodation so that if a catholic school system doesn't want to have you know, a gay person who is living in a single sex marriage as a teacher they should be able to say that.

So, my attitude is live and let live and there has to be space for a different you know, real diversity. When people talk about diversity they are not really talking about diversity. I want real diversity in our society. I want people to--to be able to find their own communities and live according to their values. I think--I think there is a group in our society you know, that views their mission as going around bludgeoning everyone into uniformity. And I said in my Notre Dame speech it's a little bit like the Roman Empire where you know, the Christians were good citizens. I mean they were the best fighters in the Roman Army--

BAKER: They were no match for the Lions though were they?

BARR: No but that was later--that was earlier. You know, and yet they wouldn't let the Christians many of the emperors would not let the Christians live in peace. They weren't satisfied unless they actually got up and sacrificed to the emperor as a God. You sort of feel a little bit of the same spirit now is that unless the little sisters of the poor provide contraception, ok, there is something horrible and outrageous going on in society. I just I don't like that.

BAKER: And we'll have to leave it there.

BARR: Thank you very much.

BAKER: Ladies and gentleman please (INAUDIBLE).

(APPLAUSE)

Thank you very much.
