urn:contentItem:605C-JSB1-JB20-G3MF-00000-00AT&T's 5G Coverage Expands Nationwide; Lyft Promises to Go All Electric By 2030; Florida, Texas and Arizona Seeing COVID-19 Cases Rise Amid Reopening Efforts; Bank of England decision today; Be Our Guest: Hong Kong Disneyland reopens in scorching heat; U.S./China Talks: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with Chinese counterpart this week; Futures search for direction; Showing Support: President Donald Trump, Colin Kaepernick should get another shot.2020-06-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:28ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTMark Tepper, Gordon Chang, Steve Forbes, Leo Kelly, Toby Cosgrove, Steve ForbesNEWSFinancial061801cb.231AT&T's 5G Coverage Expands Nationwide; Lyft Promises to Go All Electric By 2030; Florida, Texas and Arizona Seeing COVID-19 Cases Rise Amid Reopening Efforts; Bank of England decision today; Be Our Guest: Hong KongDisneyland reopens in scorching heat; U.S./China Talks: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with Chinese counterpart this week; Futures search for direction; Showing Support: President Donald Trump, Colin Kaepernick should get another shot.Mara Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Gerri Willis

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS: --that's just not acceptable.

LOUIS DOBBS, FOX NEWS HOST: And that's it for us and Investigative Reporter John Solomon justinnews.com editor and Michael Pillsbury among our guests here tomorrow will take up China what is going on? Thanks for being with us tonight.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX NEWS HOST: Welcome good Thursday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, June 18th, your top stories right now at 6:00 am on the button on the East Coast.

Coronavirus spiking as the country reopens Florida, Texas and Arizona are seeing cases increased to record highs. This morning we're getting another look at the pandemic's impact on jobs in America when the initial jobless claims report is released in about 2.5 hours.

Help for small businesses the White House making the process easier for much needed loans to be forgiven. At 8:30 am eastern this morning U. S. Small Business Administrator Jovita Carranza is here joining me exclusively on what is needed to help business owners and the White House discussions with Governors on the reopening of America?

Markets this morning look like this, Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading this morning. Take a look, the DOW Futures right now turning negative down 19 points but the NASDAQ is up 9 and the S&P 500 is also negative down about 1 point.

Mixed story this morning, the DOW the S&P 500 snapped a 3 day winning streak yesterday turning negative by the close. The DOW was down 170 points the NASDAQ was up 14 but the S&P 500 down 11.25.

U. S./China relations Secretary of State Mike Pompeo meeting with Chinese top diplomat as issues on trade, human rights and the Coronavirus heat up. And John Bolton's new book making claims about President Trump's relationship and comments with China's President Xi Jinping the President sounding off against the book as the Department of Justice fights to block its release with a lawsuit.

Protests in Atlanta to report the Former Officer that killed Rayshard Brooks has been charged with felony murder. Meanwhile on Capitol Hill Senate Republicans unveiled their police reform bill as House Democrats call for more action.

Coming up at 7:00 am eastern this morning, New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani will join me with his valuable insight on policing in America the Former Mayor today telling us his reaction to all of this.

Then cracking down on big tech Justice Department looks to limit protections enjoyed by technology companies as censorship concerns grow. "Mornings with Maria" is live right now.

Checking on global markets this morning, a negative story this morning FTSE 100 down about 12 points the CAC Quarante in Paris is down 32 and the DAX Index right now down 50 points. We are getting the Bank of England's decision today at 7 am eastern.

Investors were relooking for comments on an expansion of its bond buying program and any possible stimulus coming from the Bank of England this morning. We'll get you that news as soon as it hits.

In Asia overnight markets were mostly lower. Chinese Center for Disease Control Experts claiming the latest Coronavirus outbreak in Beijing is under control even with all the increased lockdowns. The SHANGHAI Composite was up a fraction the other major indices lower by a fraction.

Now some of the top stories that we are watching this morning, protesters surrounding Atlanta Police Headquarters as charges are filed against 2 officers involved in the death of Rayshard Brooks. Former officer Garrett Rolfe is facing 11 counts including felony murder. If convicted he could face life in prison or even the death penalty.

Officer Devin Brosnan who was first on the scene was placed on administrative duty and charged with aggravated assault. The officers have until 6:00 pm tonight to turn themselves in Attorneys for both men say they are not guilty and the video looks that way.

Newly released body camera video shows the moments Officer Rolfe attempted to perform CPR on Brooks watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Mr. Brooks keep breathing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Not just this. Meanwhile, the Atlanta Police Department addressing rumors officers are walking off the job in response to this charge. The Department is tweeting that is inaccurate however there have been more call outs than usual when it shared you the video exactly what happened when Rayshard Brooks turned on the officer and took his taser gun and then use it against him.

Several states including Texas, Arizona and Florida setting new records for COVID-19 cases in hospitalizations, Florida and Texas reporting where there are 2600 new cases with more than 1800 in Texas.

But Governors there say they are not considering another shut down because the states are better prepared to deal with the uptick. It is a different story however in Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer is extending her state of emergency order through July. It was supposed to end tomorrow. The state reported 240 new cases yesterday.

And Hong KongDisneyland reopening today with strict new safety rules, the park has been closed for nearly 6 months due to the Coronavirus pandemic. Employees enforcing the parks new facemask policy in the scorching heat it is nearly 90 degrees in Hong Kong today.

Well the White House exploring ways to boost the domestic travel industry as part of a phase for the stimulus package. President Trump recently proposing the idea of a tax credit a travel tax credit reportedly worth up to $4000 that could be spent on restaurants, hotels and theme parks the travel industry taking a one, two punch following state lockdown and social distancing amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

Of course Senate Republicans say they want to see what's worked in previous stimulus plans before considering new legislation. And Google's looking to boost its diversity in its leadership ranks by 30 percent by 2025 CEO Sundar Pichai announcing that goal in a letter to employees yesterday.

The initiative includes a sharp increase in the number of black executives at Google. The company will also create anti racism education programs and provide $175 million to help support black business owners. Ahead of the opening bell shares of Google's morning are flat as you can see.

That is the parent company Alphabet. Broke the law President Trump sounding off on his Former National Security Adviser John Bolton as the Justice Department's trying to block the release of Bolton's new book.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: He broke the law he was a wash up guy I gave me a chance. He couldn't get Senate confirms I gave it my non Senate confirmed position I could just put in there see how we work?

And I wasn't very enamored terrible, terrible the thing that he did. But he broke the law the very simple. I mean that as much as it's going to be broken this is highly classified information and he did not have approval. But it's come out now very loud and very strong.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Bolton is claiming in his new book that President Trump urged Chinese President Xi Jinping to help him win his reelection. Trump then stunningly turned the conversation to the coming U. S. President election. Writes Bolton alluding to China's economic capability and pleading with Xi to insure he wins.

He stressed the importance of farmers and increased Chinese purchases of soybeans and wheat in the electoral outcome, writes Bolton. U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer speaking out against some of Bolton's allegations calling them absolutely untrue.

Joining me right now is "The Coming Collapse of China" and the great U. S. China Tech War Author Gordon Chang also with us this morning is Fox Business's Dagen McDowell Forbes Media Chairman and Former Presidential Candidate Steve Forbes and Strategic Wealth Partners President and CEO Mark Tepper. Great to see everybody this morning, thank you so much for being here.

Gordon, it's good to have you here. You've been such as really an important student and writer of what's taking place in China? What is your reaction of this conversation that apparently took place according to John Bolton between the President and Chinese President Xi Jinping?

GORDON CHANG, "THE COMING COLLAPSE OF CHINA", AUTHOR: Robert Lighthizer was very clear in his Senate Finance Committee testimony yesterday. So right now it's up to death in doubt but even if what Bolton said was true what President Trump said to Xi Jinping was basically in line with what previous Presidents have said and their approach to China?

And that goes all the way back to Nixon but especially in the previous 2 administrations. So I don't think that approach works. I don't like it. I think it's counterproductive but none the less I'm in the minority on this and the mainstream view is what basically Trump did?

BARTIROMO: Yes, Gordon there is so many levels to the relationship with China and I know you know all of them back and forth. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo it's going to be holding this meeting this week in Hawaii with his Chinese counterpart in that few are using these talks as an opportunity to stress the need for reciprocal dealings on a number of issues.

The meeting comes amid unrest in Hong Kong as well as the global Coronavirus pandemic. As we speak there are troops facing off against one another on the China/India border and of course that's not even including all of the other behavior like the theft of intellectual property going on. What's your take in terms of the U. S./China relationship going forward?

CHANG: Well, I think the Secretary Pompeo and Young who were starting Tuesday night they can paper over differences. They can talk about it. They can continue discussions as they said they would but the fundamental problem is that Chinese foreign policy right now is extremely provocative and belligerent.

I mean it's not just with regard to the United States is with regard to for instance India as you point out where they had that Bill flash on Monday night. Also you know we're seeing dangerous intercepts of the U. S. Navy and the global comments.

China has picked up the tempo of that there all of these incidents in the South China Sea and East China Sea the threats of invasion of Taiwan, Beijing is lashing out Xi Jinping the Chinese ruler is looking for a victory. He's probably going to end up with a string of defeats and that's when China becomes even more dangerous.

So although the diplomats can talk the reality is that Xi Jinping is pushing the world in a very, very dangerous direction.

BARTIROMO: So what could come out of these talks then Gordon? I mean what's the point of having these diplomatic talks when we know about the dictatorship and the behavior of the Chinese Communist Party? Is Pompeo really going to be able to change any of these?

CHANG: I actually don't think so but I think the one thing that Secretary Pompeo can do which he is really good at doing is making it clear to China what the consequences of his actions will be? He has been extremely stern. He has actually taken measures instead of just talking about this.

And so I think that the Chinese will at least at the diplomatic level will take into account what Secretary Pompeo was saying but the problem is this not the Chinese diplomats. The problem is Xi Jinping the Chinese ruler.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And is he - I mean is there any pressure that he could face in terms of the people revolting? Let's look at this India/China conflict for example. Secretary Pompeo told me 2 weeks ago that China is - Xi Jinping is using this opportunity of the pandemic to gain more territory.

India holding funerals now for some of the 20 soldiers killed this week in a battle that they have a land border between the 2 countries. Diplomats urging both sides not to escalate the situation, but 20 people are already dead, Gordon?

CHANG: Yes. And there are a couple of folds to this story. One of them is that there are the Chinese casualties might be higher. Beijing's not talking about that. If news of casualties starts to be a particularly through the Chinese social media, Xi Jinping will be in trouble because the Chinese toll probably is higher.

But the one thing that Xi Jinping has suffered as a setback is that in India right now there is white hot anger against China. We are going to see India's - I think ripped out and replaced all Chinese telecom equipment. There is going to be this boycott which is started in the Indian population of Chinese goods.

And I think that you will see India move much closer to the United States, Japan, Vietnam and Australia and much farther away from China. This looks like a fundamental shift in Indian foreign policy because the deaths of the Indian soldiers and by the way China started despite the deaths of the Indian soldiers I think it's a turning point from which China can not actually influence India anymore.

BARTIROMO: And it certainly feels like maybe this is going to be the place where many companies decide to put supply chains in India and work with the U. S. in that regard as well to try to get the supply chains out of China.

Gordon, it's always a pleasure to see you. Thanks so much for your important insights on the subject Gordon. We'll see soon.

CHANG: Thank you so much Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you sir. Gordon Chang, joining us there. We are just getting started this morning. We've got a lot coming up later this hour I'll be speaking with Former Cleveland Clinic CEO Dr. Toby Cosgrove as some states see record spikes in new Coronavirus cases don't miss that.

And then the 7:00 am hour Former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani is here as the GOP unveils its police reform bill. Plus Merrill Lynch Wealth Management President Andy Sieg is telling me the biggest market moves he's watching this morning.

As we navigate Wall Street wrestling with reopenings as well. Democratic Senator from Delaware Chris Coons is here as Democrats and Republicans clash over what to include in that police reform legislation?

And then at 8:00 am eastern Kroger's Chairman and CEO Rodney McMullen will join us with explosive reaction to the retail giant's earnings that's coming up. And Texas Senator Ted Cruz joining me on his plans to target Google's anti conservative bias.

Then I'll speak exclusively with U. S. Small Business Administrator Jovita Carranza on the fight to save America's small business big show a lot coming up. Stay with us, we'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Futures are searching for direction this morning ahead of the weekly jobless numbers out this morning. Take a look DOW Futures are down 32 points right now. The NASDAQ is up it's up just a 7 points but the S&P is also negative down about 3 points.

Market snapped a 3 day winning streak yesterday with declines with the DOW down 170 points and the S&P down 11, the NASDAQ was up yesterday as well 14 points. There are concerns however growing over the spike of new Coronavirus cases.

Joining us right now is the CEO of Verdence Leo Kelly. Leo, great to have you this morning thanks very much. How concerned are you with the fact that as we reopen America we're seeing an increase in spikes? Is this going to take us back a few steps?

LEO KELLY, VERDENCE CEO: Well, obviously you have to be concerned at any increase in Coronavirus spikes. But I think we have to take a few other points into consideration. One is we're doing more testing so we're going to see more cases.

Secondly there's an interesting statistic in some of these states where are hospitalizations are going up where as people come back to do elective procedures they're being tested for Coronavirus so you're going to see more Coronavirus cases in hospitals as a result of all this.

So I think we have to focus on the death rate. I think we have to focus on the vulnerable. I don't think the country's going to have an appetite to do a complete shutdown again. I think the market is showing us that that's what it believes as well.

BARTIROMO: All right. So you've got initial jobless claims out this morning in about 2 hour's time. Economists are predicting another 1.3 million jobs lost in the last week that would be 44.2 million jobs lost since the end of March. Leo how does this play into how you invest today?

KELLY: Well, I think when you look at this quarter as damaging and as difficult as this quarter is in terms of the statistics are on unemployment and small businesses that's what the Fed came in to do and that's what the stimulus came into solve for was to get us through this moment.

The market is a forward forecasting mechanism and so while the jobs numbers going to be ugly today the key is what the pace of change the rate of change is? And as long as the economic data continues to improve then we have to look forward beyond what we're going through today in terms of our investment strategy?

As I've said before here on the show Maria as you know rate of change on the economy rate of change on the science and take note of the political atmosphere around shut down so those are the 3 key variables. And as long as they continue to improve the market should stay strong.

BARTIROMO: Mark Tepper?

MARK TEPPER, STRATEGIC WEALTH PARTNERS, PRESIDENT AND CEO: Leo, when it comes to putting new cash to work what your favorite sectors or industries right now?

KELLY: Well, new cash to work today is a little bit tougher proposition because the market has run its gotten - what I could see a little bit ahead of itself it's already in my opinion discounting a successful outcome for the year or almost at a high so it's a little bit more difficult today.

There are still some lagging areas like industrials and financials that are interesting the small caps continue to rebound but they've made a big run. Frankly cash is a good place to be right now. We're going to have volatility. I don't - volatility is this is in the DNA of an equity investor so holding cash isn't bad.

We also by the way like private equity. There are opportunities in the private equity world maybe not in the mainstream venture capital world but there are opportunities in private equity that give you a chance to make up a bit of a higher yield.

BARITORMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Leo, we'll be watching. We'll take a look at those PE ideas. Leo thanks so much Leo Kelly for joining us this morning. Coming up Colin Kaepernick makes a comeback President Trump is running reverse play softening his stance on the NFL stars kneeling controversy the President's take, coming up next. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Well, Colin Kaepernick may make a return to the NFL. President Trump said last night he's on board with Kaepernick returning to the league, listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: If he has the ability, if somebody would take him. You're not going to lose games because wanting to be politically correct. They had somebody that was going to win games. They will sign him it doesn't matter who they are?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And one team is giving the former quarterback a closer look, the Los Angeles Chargers Head Coach Anthony Lynn says this it would be crazy not to have him on that workout list, stay talent of that caliber that's available under these circumstances that were in right now. I would think most teams would explore that. Dagen McDowell, your reaction?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS: That it's nice to hear that from President Trump but this is - people look at Colin Kaepernick now and what he was doing to draw attention to racial injustice. The treatment of black men and women by some members of Police Departments across the country even racism taking a knee, they look back and see what he was trying to tell people particularly following the murder of George Floyd?

And I said this before in terms of what we started seeing from beginning with a NASCAR official taking a knee but saluting during the National Anthem? This is going to be a form of powerful but quiet protest across the country to draw attention to these weighty important issues and is going to be happening across sports.

And so I think the President and people who don't like it need to realize it's not political it is deeply personal for these men and women beginning with Colin Kaepernick.

BARTIROMO: That's a really good way to put it. Mark how do you see it?

TEPPER: The way I see it is the key here is Kaepernick should not be blacklisted from the league. What do the guys good enough he should be on a team but he had like one good season and then he was exposed just like RG 3 and a number of other quarterbacks. Then he didn't take his trial seriously.

And you look at quarterbacks like Jamey Winston who threw for like over 5000 yards last season but also a lot of interceptions and that guy can't get a starting job in the league. He's a backup to Drew Brees so it's all about game play here. Teams want to win and that's what's most important and if he's good enough you should be on a team.

BARTIROMO: Well, the President also weighed in on the kneeling controversy listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: When the National Anthem plays and our flag the great American flag is raised you should not be kneeling, you should be standing ideally with your hand on your heart or saluting.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: He's not changing his stance on that Steve Forbes.

STEVE FORBES, FORBES MEDIA CHAIRMAN: No he isn't. So I think he's a recognizing weather situation we have today as Dagen pointed out. And the fact that he can play a team is going to sign him, I guarantee of that. And so he will have a job coming this new season. And I think they will get that season off the ground.

But in terms of the anthem and everything else I think you're going to see a lot of the players doing the kneel whether it's the NHL, the NBA even - you may not have size and had baseball yet. I'm not sure we're going to have a season yet but that seems almost past say now given the situation we have today.

I think most fans are just going to look away and say I like it or don't like it. But they're going to be focusing on issues like the upcoming police reform bill that the GOP is introducing the Senator Scott and try to get substantive things done so that these other controversies won't be necessary because real reforms is being undertaken.

And that's the key real action if not just having to rely on symbols but getting real things done especially in getting police transparency with the unions.

BARTIROMO: And I think that's what the White House is trying to do as well? Some real changes actually. I will - we'll be talking about that coming up. Then also coming up Americans are eager to get back to work but certain states are seeing a record spike in new Coronavirus cases after rolling back restrictions what it could mean for recovery coming up?

Plus a rearranged marriage how brides and grooms are reshaping their traditional wedding plans amid the Coronavirus pandemic? We wish you hear this, stay with us.

MARIA BARTIROMO, ANCHOR, MORNINGS WITH MARIA: Welcome back, good Thursday morning everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, June 18th. Your top stories right now, it is 6:31 a.m. on the East Coast. There are concerns growing over coronavirus spike as the country reopens. Florida, Texas, Arizona are all seeing cases rise to record highs. Futures meanwhile are searching for direction this morning.

Take a look at stocks, the Dow is down 24, the Nasdaq is up, it's up at 8 points and the S&P is down 2 and a half. Similar story yesterday when the Dow and the S&P 500 snapped a three-day winning streak, but the Nasdaq was actually higher at 4 O'clock on Wall Street. The Dow is down 170 points with the Nasdaq was up 14, the S&P was down 11 at the close yesterday.

Global markets this morning look like this, European indices right now are lower across the board, we are waiting on the Bank of England's decision today at 7:00 a.m. Eastern, investors are looking for an expansion of its bond-buying program, and any news of any possible stimulus for England. The FTSE 100 right now is down about -- under 1 point, the CAC Quarante in Paris is down 20, and the Dax index in Germany lower by 26.

In Asia overnight, markets are mostly lower there as well. Chinese Center for Disease Control is claiming that the latest coronavirus outbreak in Beijing is under control, nonetheless, we told you last -- yesterday, rather, that the entire city is being closed in terms of schools, et cetera. Shanghai Composite was up a fraction, the others were lower. Hertz is slamming the brakes on a proposed sale of New York -- of new stock. Cheryl Casone with the details there. They were going to do a secondary, right, Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS: Yes, Maria, and this is a company -- let's remind everybody, that's in Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. So this raises a lot of eyebrows. Now, Hertz has suspended that plan to sell up to $500 million in new shares after the Securities and Exchange Commission raised questions about the deal, Hertz was looking to take advantage of a recent rally in its stock which sent shares as high as 553 each.

Investors piled into the stock even after the company warned these new shares could be worthless. Hertz was forced to idle about 700,000 vehicles because of the COVID-19 pandemic. There's the stock in the pre-market, back down to a buck 81, a loss of 9.5 percent in the premarket -- and by the way, the stock was halted for several hours yesterday. Well, Conagra brands says it's going to do a complete brand and packaging review of Mrs. Butterworth's syrups after the Quaker Oats company announced plans to retire its Aunt Jemima brand because it is based on racial stereotypes and doesn't represent company values.

But they're not the only logic corporation making changes, Mars' own Uncle Ben is also changing its look. The company is telling Fox Business, it doesn't plan on replacing the products, but they're going to focus on evolving the Uncle Ben's brand. Finally, let us look at what is trending this morning on foxbusiness.com, AT&T's 5G network is expected to reach nationwide coverage this Summer.

Currently, it covers more than 160 million people and 327 markets. Lyft pledging every vehicle in its platform is going to be electric by 2030, but it's not providing financial support to drivers to make the switch. And for today only, Blaze Pizza, Maria, it's offering its pizza with a mango- flavored white claw hard seltzer crust at 40 of its locations.

This by the way is LeBron James' pizza company. I know you're a pizza purist, so I don't know how you feel about that, but that's what they're going to do.

BARTIROMO: Well, I like all small businesses to thrive, so there's that, but yes, I'm you know, I'm a purist, thank you, Cheryl.

CASONE: Good to know.

BARTIROMO: Well, record coronavirus spikes across the country, we are talking about thousands of new cases this week in Florida, Texas and Arizona, but none of the governors in those states pushing to shut down again after pushing for reopening. President Trump is touting the economic resurgence the country has seen since reopening. He talked on Hannity last night.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If we had to turn it off, we would have lost millions of people, we did, we turned it off, and now we've started up again and we're going to have an amazing year next year. We're going to have a great third quarter. We just had the best job's numbers, the biggest job gain in history, and we just had the biggest retail sales numbers in history for the last month.

SEAN HANNITY, FOX NEWS: Yes --

TRUMP: So we're starting up and it's going to be very strong.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is the former CEO of the Cleveland Clinic, Dr. Toby Cosgrove. And Toby, it is always a pleasure to see you. Thank you so much --

TOBY COSGROVE, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, CLEVELAND CLINIC: Good morning, Maria --

BARTIROMO: For being here this morning.

COSGROVE: Well, thank you, my pleasure.

BARTIROMO: So what strikes you first -- I'm sorry, so what strikes you first about where we are in the coronavirus? I have your op-ed that you wrote a couple of months ago in terms of needing an army of healthcare workers. So I'm going to get to that in a moment. But anything so far in terms of this reopening and these spikes that we're seeing that strikes you?

COSGROVE: Well, Maria, I think where we have to understand that we're going to be living with this pandemic for a very long period of time, that you have to remember that there's only been one viral disease that's totally eliminated from the face of the earth, and that's smallpox, we have all the rest of them with us. So even if we can get a vaccination, we're still going to have to understand that this is a new disease that we're going to have to deal with for a long time. So it's changed our culture.

BARTIROMO: And so how do we deal with that? Just what we're doing in terms of the guidelines, masks, gloves, anything else that we should be doing, knowing that this is here for some time and a vaccine doesn't happen overnight?

COSGROVE: No, it certainly doesn't, but I think we also have to appreciate the fact that 80 percent of the deaths have been in people who are over 65 years of age, and if you're under 65 years of age, the risk of dying of COVID infection is about the same as your risk of getting in a car accident and driving to work in the morning. So it's really very low and particularly low amongst young children.

So, that's a fortunate thing for younger people. But we have to protect older people, and the way you protect them is -- you don't put them in large crowds, you wear masks, you don't have long periods together with people, and those are the things that protect people over time.

BARTIROMO: So it's really one of the reasons Vice President Mike Pence wrote an op-ed this week saying that there's no second wave, he's touting efforts by the administration to expand testing and research. Pence is blaming the media for overshadowing efforts, writing, quote, "the media has tried to scare the American people every step of the way and these grim predictions of a second wave are no different.

The truth is whatever the media says, our whole-of-America approach has been a success." What's your take on that, Toby, in terms of this potential second wave. You say, look, this is here with us, we've got to deal with it and we all have to adapt.

COSGROVE: Yes, exactly. And Dr. Fauci, I think made it very clear that we haven't got the second wave yet, we're continuing to see this first problem that we're dealing with, and we're going to continue to have to deal with it for a long time. One of the things that concerns me is --

BARTIROMO: Let me talk to you about what you've -- yes, go ahead --

COSGROVE: One of the things that concerns me is 30 percent of the people said that they wouldn't get a vaccine initially, and that is going to leave a repository of infections that will continue to be with us.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. A lot of people refuse to get vaccines regardless and --

COSGROVE: Yes --

BARTIROMO: Overall. You've been talking about this healthcare ready reserve trained by U.S. Armed Forces, so you write an op-ed on health soldiers saying that we could train 1 million people over 3 to 12 months on military bases for around $50 billion. You say that both of the problems can be solved at least partially in the same solution establishment of a million strong healthcare ready reserve. Tell us more about this.

COSGROVE: Well, I think this is an idea that John Dreskell(ph), a friend of mine came up with, and I thought it was a great idea, and basically is going back to WPA, what happened after the great depression? We're dealing with two things, frankly, we're dealing with a disease and we're dealing with unemployment. And this is an opportunity to train people that will be healthcare providers in the future.

This would be much like a National Guard is today to be called out, and it will provide employment, it will provide salaries and it will also benefit the country. And I think this is an opportunity that is bigger than just providing a straight financial aid to people, it gives them the dignity of a job and it provides additional support for the country to continue.

Think about contact-tracing for example, we don't have enough contact- tracers in many states, this would provide those sorts of individuals. And I think that you do have an opportunity to begin to develop a force that will begin to look at floods or hurricanes or any sort of natural disasters as well as epidemics in the future.

BARTIROMO: I love the idea. I think to me, it falls under the umbrella of national security. You know, it's almost like we --

COSGROVE: Yes --

BARTIROMO: You know, the fact that we have to import 70 percent of the active ingredients in our drugs, that this is just not acceptable. I mean, this is, again, under national security, we need to have this -- the training as you say for a healthcare professionals as well as the drugs we need accessible and at-the ready. So have you shared this idea, Toby, with the administration?

COSGROVE: Yes, I have. I've shared it as lively as I can. There are senators now, Senator Sullivan from Alaska, for example, is starting to put together a bill in the Senate, and I hope that we will use some of the money that has been directed to -- for COVID to sort of an opportunity. I think it is going to be vital for unemployment and good for the country.

BARTIROMO: Right, Toby, real quick before you go, I know you've worked a lot on technology and technology enabling healthcare. Can you talk to us about any jobs that you see in the future in that realm?

COSGROVE: Yes, I think that we have to really begin to think about technology, helping us understand the opportunities there are from these huge data sets. And AI, and I think is going to be enormous opportunity to do that, and the use of the huge data sets that are being accumulated now through electronic medical records.

I think it's possible to have privacy and also use those -- that data to improve the quality of care for people and be great for predicting of disease propensity. This opportunity is to do this or enormous we're seeing all kinds of interesting ways now to begin to track the, you know, testing, using your cell phones and technologies. This is great opportunities and I think technology is going to explode.

One of the things that has taken off is through this whole epidemic is the use of telemedicine. Tele-medicine at the clinic went from 2 percent to 75 percent of the visits, over a two-month period --

BARTIROMO: Wow --

COSGROVE: Of time, 94 percent of diabetics were treated this way. I could imagine now that you're no longer going to need to go to the hospital to get your blood-sugar checked or your blood pressure taken, it all can be done from home and probably regulated much more efficiently than it ever has in the past. This is a whole new world that is opening up and how you treat patients, and I think people will be moving increasingly to outpatient and to homecare as a result of this. A major change that technology is bringing to the delivery of healthcare.

BARTIROMO: I love it. I love it. It's a new day in that regard. Toby Cosgrove, it's always a pleasure to see you, thanks so much.

COSGROVE: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: We'll see you soon. Toby Cosgrove, but we'll be right back, stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, wedding bell blues. The coronavirus pandemic forcing many couples to change their plans to their upcoming wedding. More couples are passing on the vows and just living the together. As our Gerri Willis reports, there are benefits on both sides of that aisle.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

GERRI WILLIS, TELEVISION JOURNALIST: It's June and usually that means wedding season, but this year, thousands of couples have postponed because of COVID-19. But for now, they're in good company when it comes to staying committed without getting hitched. Millions of committed couples choose never to get married in the first place. Listen to my friend Jeane Meyer on why she decided not to tie the knot.

JEANE MEYER, MARKETING CONSULTANT: Both of us had short-term marriages that ended in divorce, and I think the primary reason is that the divorce in particular was a very unpleasant process -- you know, it wasn't our first rodeo.

WILLIS: The percentage of partners who don't get married has tripled in the last two decades. Marriage rates are at their lowest level in over 100 years and the trend is gaining steam with Gen Z couples 24 and under more likely to live together than be married. But experts say what's love got to do with it? There are more than a thousand tax breaks, benefits and protections for married couples like tax benefits, employee benefits, even housing benefits.

MARILYN CHINITZ, PARTNER, BLANK ROME LLP: So there's very significant reasons I think that you want to take advantage of the marital laws because it provides you with the opportunity to enhance and preserve that wealth which is very important for most people.

WILLIS: Primary amongst those benefits inheriting your spouse's assets when they pass away without paying any federal or estate taxes. In fact, spouses can exchange financial gifts completely tax-free. So with so many financial benefits on the table, why choose not to marry?

CHINITZ: Well, you maintain your own assets, you maintain your own wealth, and there are clearly benefits to being single because number one, you maintain your financial autonomy, no one is telling you what to do.

WILLIS: The number of older couples who get together but don't marry has tripled over the last two decades, the reason? Social security. Getting hitched can reduce benefits significantly. Also marriage can threaten the inheritance for any children from previous relationships. That said, committed couples who aren't married can tackle those issues with contracts and wills. As for Jeane, she says she only has one regret.

MEYER: Because we never had an official wedding date, we don't really celebrate an anniversary. Every now and then, I think, it would be nice to have an actual wedding anniversary.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WILLIS: Maria, for me, I made my decision years ago last week, I celebrated my 26th wedding anniversary. So far, it's working out. Back to you.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: How fantastic, thank you, Gerri. And I just celebrated 21, more MORNINGS WITH MARIA right after this. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, time for the morning buzz. First up, Spotify brings to star power to its podcast roster. Kim Kardashian, West inking a new deal for an exclusive series on a case involving criminal justice reform. Mark Tepper, will you tune in?

MARK TEPPER, PRESIDENT & CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, STRATEGIC WEALTH PARTNERS: Yes, actually, I mean, look, Spotify right now, they seem to be the big winner in the podcast war. I mean, they landed Joe Rogan, maybe a month ago, and now they got Kim K. And the deal is this, I mean, Joe Rogan became disgruntled with YouTube and their censorship. I mean, you know, we all know that Google right now has the federal list than zero had in its crosshair.

So censorship is a big issue. You know, you're supposed to be able to say what you want on a podcast, and then people have the choice to listen or not. So, I think Spotify is definitely going to be the big winner here.

BARTIROMO: Interesting. Next up here are the tweets. Twitter trying out audio tweets now where users can now share thoughts in audio form. Dagen?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK: So if Kim Kardashian tweets, fam, I wonder what it's going to sound like as she does on audio tweets because again, who wants to listen to a podcast? Listening to that valley girl voice for any -- longer than 15 seconds. So audio tweets -- I just wonder if people will be as nasty if they audio tweet you as they are on Twitter was in responding to things that you might say because like there is so much venom and vile out there, I think folks need to go to church.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and if you start just saying it, maybe you're doing too many knee-jerk reactions in an audio tweet. How about this? Not so fast. A new study shows half of Americans are not quite ready to go back to the office yet due to concerns over health and safety. The same study shows 40 percent of Americans have bosses who are not forcing them to come back, Steve, what do you think?

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Well, that's changed, and I think, you will have people coming back more as we get effective treatments and later this year we get a vaccine. But in terms of interaction with people, I think there's no substitute for that. Yes, you can get a lot of work done at home, perhaps more work if the kids stay out of the way or grandkids stay out of the way.

But the fact of the matter is offices are being reconfigured. We're doing the same thing that our offices will be opening in a few weeks. And people want safety, but they do need that interaction. So you might call up masking anxieties, you put the mask on and I think people will interact. This is not going to be a permanent. It will be a mix. It'll be a mix.

BARTIROMO: All right, still ahead, former New York City Mayor Rudy Giuliani is here this morning as Democrats and Republicans clash over what to include in police reform legislation. He's right here next hour with MORNINGS WITH MARIA, stay with us.

urn:contentItem:5XNK-D9M1-F03R-N2SP-00000-00ATT Says The Real Problem With The Internet Is We Pay Too Much Attention To Giant ISPs2019-12-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:28ZLexisNexisATT Says The Real Problem With The Internet Is We Pay Too Much Attention To Giant ISPsKarl Bode

Dec 05, 2019( Techdirt: http://www.techdirt.com Delivered by Newstex) As Silicon Valley giants like Google and Facebook face all manner of (justified) regulatory scrutiny, telecom has been able to somehow remove itself from the conversation[1], despite engaging in many of the same[2] (if not worse[3]) behaviors over the years. While Congress obsesses about new ways to regulate "big tech," the US government has oddly been busy neutering all oversight of "big telecom"[4]. That's at least partially by design; giants like AT...nd Comcast have spent years[5] pushing for the hyper regulation of companies telecom increasingly competes with in the online ad space. The result: as Silicon Valley faces an endless cavalcade of daily DC and press outrage, the telecom sector has suddenly little to no scrutiny whatsoever. Whether it's the speed at which the competition-eroding T-Mobile merger is being shoveled through the DOJ and FCC[6], or the blind eye being turned to major telecom privacy scandals[7] (like location data), telecom lobbyists have been on a successful tear convincing well-heeled DC lawmakers to ignore the massive, obvious monopoly, privacy, and competition issues inherent in telecom to focus exclusively on the problems in "big tech."

AT... top lobbying and policy man, Jim Cicconi, was recently brought out of retirement[8] to (in part) help tackle both the looming privacy minefield and an ongoing revolt among investors who have grown tired of AT... focus on growth for growth's sake[9]. In a treatise nobody asked for[10], Cicconi this week shared his thoughts[11] on recent missives at the NY Times[12] exploring how the bloom of optimism has fallen from the internet rose in recent years. The Times package focuses on everything from US broadband coverage woes to the rise of internet misinformation. But Cecconi's takeaway from the package, unsurprisingly, is somehow that broadband providers are yesterday's news and no longer worth talking about:"Notably, nowhere does the series discuss internet service provider (ISP)-based open internet misconduct or concerns, and for good reason. As intervening events in the last few years have dramatically exposed how the internet is being used, misused and manipulated by a variety of internet players, ISP-centric arguments have quickly become yesterday's policy story."This idea that the hugely unpopular telecom sector is an innocent little angel and Silicon Valley is the only real problem has been a narrative telecom giants have been pushing for a while[13], and with pretty notable success if you've tracked DC policy conversations and the newswires. But because the Times didn't bother mentioning how telecom is nearly as terrible[14] on privacy as Facebook, doesn't make it untrue. Of course Cicconi and AT... real goal is to ensure that whatever regulation and legislation comes from this era of reckoning, it won't include big telecom:"Yet for the past decade plus, the internet policy debate has been focused almost solely on ISPs, to the exclusion of other online actors. That regulatory myopia has in turn produced the internet we didn't expect. The true costs and challenges of an interconnected world, which are now only starting to be more fully understood, are the issues that today demand our time, energy and best ideas. As we look back on the debate, I hope that the signs and signals we missed previously will illuminate our path forward."That's total fantasy. The telecom sector has spent billions of dollars to eliminate consumer protections and government oversight of its businesses over the last few decades. That recently culminated in the FCC's decision to effectively self-immolate[15] at industry's behest, shoveling any remaining telecom oversight to an FTC that lacks the authority or resources[16] to police the sector effectively. The end result: a total accountability vacuum that's letting the telecom sector rip off customers with relative impunity, provided they're moderately clever about it[17]. Our friend Jim is worried about one thing: that Congress and the states will ruin AT... string of good luck with new laws and regulation focused on subjects like privacy and an open internet. And he'd sure appreciate it if the most unpopular business sector in America, fresh on the heels of thirty years of anticompetitive behavior, is excluded entirely from the conversation.Permalink[18] | urn:contentItem:5RKG-4YF1-JCMN-Y2H5-00000-00ATT's Clash With Washington Benefitting Big Tech: Report2018-02-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:27ZLexisNexisATT's Clash With Washington Benefitting Big Tech: ReportDominik Bosnjak

Feb 06, 2018( Android Headlines: http://androidheadlines.com Delivered by Newstex) AT... clash with Washington over its proposed acquisition of Time Warner is benefitting the Silicon Valley and its growing ambitions in the entertainment sector, CNBC reports, citing numerous industry watchers. The Department of Justice sued to block AT... merger late last year as part of a move that surprised most analysts and even the wireless carrier itself, prompting it to delay its deadline for the completion of the deal while publicly expressing its befuddlement[1] with the development.

And while the antitrust regulator is trying to break more than a century old precedent in regards to vertical consolidations, big tech is still freely investing in the segment, with the likes of Amazon, Netflix, Google, and even Facebook now committing significant sums to original video content. Leo Hindery of InterMedia Partners was quoted by CNBC as saying that this is the first period in his career over which he's reluctant to predict what kind of a reaction could the federal regulators have to any proposed mergers, vertical or otherwise, criticizing Washington's 'inconsistent strategies' in regards to approaching big business tie-ups. Whereas the Silicon Valley is still committing billions to boosting its video programming, some traditional media players feel they are unfairly limited by antitrust regulations, with that gap in regulatory policies becoming even more pronounced after the DOJ decided to break from precedent and challenge AT... proposal in court. That state of affairs is also what partially prompted Rupert Murdoch to accept Disney's $52.4 billion bid for the majority of 21st Century Fox last month, some sources claim. The high-profile deal may not be as straightforward as originally announced, with Comcast supposedly considering outbidding Disney for the assets if AT...] succeeds in defending its proposed acquisition in the court of law, though Disney is understood to already be planning for such a scenario. Mr. Murdoch recently publicly criticized social media companies for their role in the demise of not just traditional media but digital outlets as well, claiming companies like Facebook should pay[3] any website whose content their users are taking. The media mogul is understood to be skeptical of Fox's long-term prospects as uneven regulatory pressure and other obstacles may allow the Silicon Valley to outbid the firm for valuable content in the future, making Disney's offer an apt opportunity for him to cash out. urn:contentItem:5WPX-VR41-F03R-N2HM-00000-00ATT Scores $1 Billion Contract To Rebuild DOJ Systems2019-08-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:28ZLexisNexisATT Scores $1 Billion Contract To Rebuild DOJ SystemsKarl Bode

Aug 02, 2019( Techdirt: http://www.techdirt.com Delivered by Newstex) AT...s increasingly becoming one of those companies that's so bone-grafted to the government, it's getting harder to determine where the telecom giant ends and the government begins. Reports have already explored how AT...s effectively fused to the NSA[1]; the company provides the government widespread access to every shred of data that traverses its network, and its employees can often be found acting as government intelligence analysts[2]. Granted after some early concerns about corruption[3], AT...as also been tasked with building the nation's $47 billion emergency communications network, FirstNet. And this week the company also netted a new $1 billion, fifteen-year contract[4] to rebuild the Department of Justice's computer systems:"AT...as won a $984 million, 15-year contract to help upgrade the US Department of Justice's technology systems.

The deal will see AT...ove more than 120,000 DOJ employees in 2,100 offices to a new communications platform for mobile voice and data, cybersecurity and cloud services. While it doesn't cover 5G for now, the next-generation networking service could be added on later."Aside from that whole DOJ lawsuit against the Time Warner merger (which was likely more about pleasing Rupert Murdoch[5] than reining in corporate power), AT...as been having a hell of a run under the Trump administration. It not only got to effectively hand pick[6] the head of the FCC, it then was showered with incalculable billions in regulatory favors (like killing net neutrality and broadband privacy rules[7]), before getting showered in billions more in favors thanks to the Trump tax cut. The problem of fusing a historically anti-competitive monopoly to government should be fairly obvious. Especially given AT... repeated ethical challenges. This is a company that in just the last few years AT...as been: fined $18.6 million[8] for helping rip off programs for the hearing impaired, fined $10.4 million[9] for ripping off a program for low-income families, fined $105 million[10] for helping "crammers" (by intentionally making such bogus charges more difficult to see on customer bills), and fined $7.7 million[11] for turning a blind eye while drug dealers ran a directory assistance scam on its customers. That's before you even get to AT... routinely anti-competitive behavior[12], concern over which has been widely sidelined given the laser-like focus on "big tech." Recent tech policy conversations almost exclusively focus on Silicon Valley giants, yet oddly exclude the threat of telecom monopolies from the conversation, another Trump era favor to AT...Of course telecom lobbyists are more than happy[13] to have the entirety of recent policy conversations fixated on "big tech" and not telecom, given the latter is trying desperately to disrupt the former's stranglehold over online advertising. Which is all to say that maybe at some point in addition to trying to fix the problems with "big tech," we could shift at least a portion of the tech policy conversation back to unethical, anti-competitive telecom monopolies we're happily bone-grafting to the US government? urn:contentItem:5Y98-DGX1-F05M-K2T1-00000-00AT&T's new COO: 'Really concerned' about concentration of power at Big Tech2020-02-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:28ZLexisNexisAT&T's new COO: 'Really concerned' about concentration of power at Big TechBrian Womack

AT&T's John Stankey wasn't exactly easy on Big Tech in a recent interview.

"I'm really concerned about the concentration of economic power that's occurring in some of the new tech companies - and of course, then, what occurs in terms of their practices around how they think about those platforms' influence in society," Stankey said during an interview with Yahoo! Finance, according to a transcript of the chat on its website.

The comments came after Stankey, who was named to the role of COO last year at the Dallas telecommunications and media company, was asked about Facebook, Google, social media and Twitter. Stankey went on to single out the CEO of the world's largest social-networking service.

"I heard some comments the other day that Mark Zuckerberg made that said he thinks he's somewhere between a distribution company like a telephone company and a media company, and therefore they should be handled differently," Stankey said. "And I kind of said, you know, why did editorial integrity show up in media companies? ... Well, editorial integrity and editors arrived because people needed to make sure that their source of information was, in fact, doing that ethical and fair reporting."

Stankey had earlier referenced the news efforts at CNN in the interview.

Stankey raised concerns about the tech companies as they come under growing scrutiny about how they use personal information and provide information to the masses. Big Tech already has faced U.S. Congressional hearings, regulatory pressure and other challenges as the companies rise to become some of the largest corporations in the world.

The AT&T exec sees more oversight from governments in the future for Big Tech. AT&T (NYSE: T) itself is coming off a huge battle with the U.S. Department of Justice last year over antitrust concerns with its acquisition of Time Warner, a fight that it won in court.

"It's inevitable that there's going to be some more regulation on some of the tech platforms based on what we're learning and what we're seeing in terms of how they're operating their businesses," Stankey said.

urn:contentItem:5SJB-3041-DYJW-X2T8-00000-00AT&T-Time Warner Analysis: Judge Puts Legal Framework on Forces of Disruption in Media2018-06-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:28ZLexisNexisAT&T-Time Warner Analysis: Judge Puts Legal Framework on Forces of Disruption in Media

The 172-page opinion in the AT&T-   Time Warner anti-trust case makes it clear that U.S. District Court Judge Richard Leon did his homework to understand the seismic shifts that have rocked the pay TV marketplace during the past decade.The trial in D.C. federal court wasn't just about whether the union of   AT&T and   Time Warner would be bad for consumers.

The proceedings wound up putting a legal framework for examining how traditional media giants are responding to the forces of disruption: the rise of SVOD giants, the Peak TV phenomenon and the steady drumbeat of cord cutting and its impact on the bottom line of TV programmers and distributors alike."It is inescapable that SVODs have played a large role in causing the demand for and continued purchase or traditional MVPD subscriptions to "declin[e] at a rapid pace," Leon wrote, citing a quote from AT&T chairman-CEO Randall Stephenson. "To ignore those industry trends - trends that are transforming how consumers view video content and blurring the lines between programming, distribution, and web-based competitors - would be to ignore the Supreme Court's direction to examine this case with an eye toward the 'structure, history, and probable future' of this fast-changing industry. I, of course, cannot do that!"Leon's opinion repeatedly cites the challenges facing traditional media conglomerates amid the rise of Netflix, Amazon, Facebook, and other hugely capitalized digital behemoths. The judge offers lengthy discourse on how the digital heavyweights are advantaged by the Big Data they cull from the viewing activity on their platforms. He also discusses the unique structure of the SVOD giants in serving as both a distributor with direct customer relationships and a programming service offering exclusive original series. Even in a vertically integrated media conglomerate such as Comcast, the cable service and programming operations are usually separated by distinct divisions. Netflix, on the other hand, is an all-in-one service that has direct relationships with subscribers but at a much lower cost than traditional MVPD service.Leon notes the hyper-competitive impact of Netflix barreling into the programming arena with as much as $8 billion to spend on original and acquired content, which as he cites in the opinion "is more than twice the size of HBO's" programming budget. He also points to the shift in consumer behavior toward preferring ad-free platforms."After all, as Nobel Laureate Bob Dylan correctly observed: You don't need a weatherman to know which way the wind blows," Leon wrote, quoting a lyric from Dylan's 1965 anthem "Subterranean Homesick Blues." Moreover, he rejects the government's rationale that the market power of a combined AT&T-Time Warner needed to be considered outside of the context of the larger pay-TV market, echoing the assertions of CEOs and moguls for more than a decade. Leon's legal reasoning will undoubtedly be cited by companies in future regulatory proceedings at the FCC and Justice Department."Although the government is of course correct that the refrain 'we are getting killed in by new competition in different markets' is no 'defense to an illegal merger,' I simply cannot evaluate the government's theories and predictions of harm, as presented by the Government at trial, without factoring in the dramatic changes that are transforming how consumers view video content."The judge's opinion was so strongly in favor of AT&T that he went so far as to endorse the telco giant's projection of realizing $1.5 billion in cost savings by 2021 from the consolidation of overlapping administrative departments. "I have a high degree of confidence that the defendants will generate most, if not all, of the predicted $1.5 billion in annual cost savings," he wrote.Leon's opinion took an exhaustive look at the facts and theories traded in the AT&T case no doubt because he is aware of its impact on future media M&A activity at this tumultuous time of disruption and reinvention. He notes that the trial generated some 3,000 pages of documents, and that the transcript of the court proceedings over the six-week trial runs some 4,300-pages.He concluded his opus opinion with a warning that the government should not take any more steps to block the completion of AT&T and Time Warner deal, now scheduled for June 20. For the government to seek a stay of his order pending their appeal would do far more harm than good, even for those in the Justice Department who strongly believe that the deal is bad for competition."To use a stay to accomplish indirectly what could not be done directly - especially when it would cause certain irreparable harm to the defendants - simply would be unjust. I hope and trust that the government will have the good judgment, wisdom, and courage to avoid such a manifest injustice," Leon wrote. "To do otherwise, I fear, would undermine the faith in our system of justice of not only the defendants, but their millions of shareholders and the business community at large."Read the full ruling below:AT&T Decision by   gmaddaus on ScribdRelated stories   Time Warner: Political 'Motivation' Was Behind Antitrust Lawsuit   AT&T-Time Warner Merger Decision Inspires Mixed Emotions in Hollywood   AT&T Decision Could Send Content Companies Rushing Into Big Tech's Arms

urn:contentItem:5SJB-3041-DYJW-X2TN-00000-00AT&T-Time Warner Merger Decision Inspires Mixed Emotions in Hollywood2018-06-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:28ZLexisNexisAT&T-Time Warner Merger Decision Inspires Mixed Emotions in Hollywood

On Tuesday afternoon, there was only one media story that mattered to the entertainment business. Across Hollywood, the talk was almost exclusively about the pending federal court ruling on AT&T's $85 billion bid for   Time Warner, the company behind Warner Bros., HBO, and CNN.Work screeched to a halt Tuesday afternoon on Warner Bros.'s Burbank lot and in   Time Warner's sprawling mid-town Manhattan office complex as employees gathered around televisions, scrolled through Twitter, and kept checking their phones for updates.There was a palpable sense of relief and even some scattered applause, insiders said, when word finally came that U.S. District Court Judge Richard Leon had upheld the merger. Employees on both coasts were largely relieved by the sweeping nature of Leon's decision. The judge rejected the Justice Department's lawsuit claiming that the marriage of the telecom giant and the entertainment company represented an anti-trust violation and imposed no conditions on the merger."We've been in a holding pattern for so long," said one Time Warner employee. "At least now we have some clarity."

AT&T presented the deal as a win for consumers, saying the merger means "we can begin to give consumers video entertainment that is more affordable, mobile, and innovative." But most industry observers think the big winners will be corporate lawyers, bankers, and moguls, all of whom are poised to benefit from a coming wave of media consolidation."It's not the summer of love," said one studio executive. "It's the summer of chaos."Comcast, emboldened by the judge's rubber stamping of the AT&T/Time Warner deal, is expected to formally make an offer on Wednesday for most of Fox's film and television assets. The cable giant hopes to play spoiler, potentially plucking Fox away from the Walt Disney Company, which has a deal to buy the bulk of the company. At the very least Comcast will drive the price for Fox above the $52.4 billion in stock that Disney is currently offering.Many industry figures believe that the AT&T and Time Warner deal will have a domino effect, potentially putting companies like Lionsgate, MGM, or Sony in play as bigger companies hope to capitalize on a more laissez-faire regulatory climate."It's off to the races," said one entertainment industry executive. "Whether you're Apple or Amazon or someone with a big wad of cash, this gives you the greenlight to go shopping."That's a good thing for tech giants looking to buy content makers, but it's a bad thing for job security. There's already a lot of uncertainty on the Fox lot, where executives were busy mapping out their post-Disney plans - Some were thrilled to have received the silent nod they'd be part of the Magic Kingdom, others were aggrieved to have realized that Bob Iger's team had little need for them, and a more entrepreneurial group were already mapping out new landing spots. The entrance of Comcast complicates that kind of long-term strategizing.Those concerns extend beyond the Fox rank-and-file."There have been lots of questions by talent who wonder should I make a movie or a show there?" said the industry executive. "They don't know who is going to be in control."There are a few contrarians who believe it's hyperbolic to think the AT&T and Time Warner deal will open the floodgates on merger activity."I don't buy the theory this is going to change the world," said Richard Gelfond, CEO of IMAX. "Some things that were in the works for awhile will happen now, but I don't think there's going to be dozens of transactions."Entertainment industry labor unions voiced anger over the court's decision. The Writers Guild of America, East, for instance, released a blistering statement linking the AT&T and Time Warner decision with recent efforts to weaken net neutrality protections."Never before has so much programming been under the domination of so few massive media and technology corporations," the guild's statement reads. "At a time when the country demands, and needs, the broadest possible set of views and stories and voices, we have handed over the keys to the media kingdom to giants whose sole motivation is to maximize their short-term investment return, not to inform or enlighten or entertain. Monopolies and oligopolies are bad for the economy in general, and for people who care about compelling stories and insightful reporting, in particular."The Writers Guild of America, West echoed its cousin to the East, noting that it had supported the Justice Department's effort to squelch the AT&T-Time Warner union."A combined AT&T-Time Warner, like so many mergers before it, will lead to higher prices and fewer choices," the group said in a statement. "Further, it will pave the way for more anti-competitive mega-mergers, like the forthcoming Comcast-NBCU-Fox tie-up."IMAX's Gelfond disagrees. He argues the Justice Department was using an overly broad definition of monopolies"The media landscape is changing so rapidly that it would have messed up the business if this had been allowed to go through," said Gelfond. "Today's decision is good for the industry, and it's good for the country."Related stories   Time Warner: Political 'Motivation' Was Behind Antitrust Lawsuit   AT&T-Time Warner Merger Decision Inspires Mixed Emotions in Hollywood   AT&T Decision Could Send Content Companies Rushing Into Big Tech's Arms

urn:contentItem:5R9M-RWK1-JC8G-92B1-00000-00AT&T/TW, Disney/Fox Seen Spurring More Cable, Content M&A in 20182018-01-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:16:28ZLexisNexisTOP NEWSAT&T/TW, Disney/Fox Seen Spurring More Cable, Content M&A in 2018

AT&T's bid for Time Warner and Disney's quest for Fox likely will lead to even more video industry mergers and acquisitions in 2018, particularly as mid-sized programmers and distributors look to scale up or get assets that will let them compete in an increasingly direct-to-consumer (DTC) marketplace, experts said. "If you're a Viacom or a Discovery or an AMC, you have to look at [the consolidation trends] and say, 'Wow, we're becoming more fringe than core,'" said Andre James, head of Bain & Co.'s Americas media and entertainment practice.

Given the slowing of the pay-TV market in the U.S., plus the desire by content companies to get closer to customers and have more data about them for marketing, content investment and targeted advertising via DTC offerings, the choices are either vertically integrate like AT&T/TW or scale up like Disney/Fox, James said. That Verizon, Comcast and Sony all seemingly were interested in Fox shows there's sizable interest in M&A, and "a lot of assets on the block," he said.

Also driving such activity in the coming year is the expectation the regulatory environment is amenable, despite the DOJ challenge to AT&T/TW (see 1711210005), experts said. AT&T/TW and Disney/Fox were driven in part by that regulatory perception, plus that both are in maturing spaces that lead to players looking for increased scale via M&A, said S&P Global Market Intelligence Research Director-Media Ian Olgeirson. But whether the regulatory environment is friendlier "remains a question mark," Olgeirson said.

Some see the trend of MVPD consolidation losing steam. TV industry analyst Alan Wolk said the looming arrival of 5G and its potential for rivaling home broadband could make MVPDs less attractive as an investment. But as the broadband market continues maturing, there could be more willing cable ISP sellers as they see broadband start to face an uphill battle, Olgeirson said. He also said 5G's introduction "is a double-edged sword" for cable operators, with competing high-bandwidth high-throughput wireless service posing a competitive challenge to wireline operators, but 5G also requiring a dense last-mile infrastructure to serve small cells. Small and mid-sized cable ISPs are seeing "a lot of speculation" about whether it's a good time to combine, given 5G issues, said American Cable Association President Matt Polka.

AT&T/TW will likely be consummated next year with a settlement just before the March trial, while Disney/Fox "breeze[s]" through regulatory approval, said tech and media investor Eric Jackson, president of EMJ Capital, in a newsletter Wednesday. He predicted an "M&A bonanza" next year, with the market slightly sour on initial public offerings, saying that bonanza will include "more mega-mergers and ... some of the smaller media companies ... to be digested by their larger siblings." Other deals potentially in the wings include Verizon/CBS, since CBS has no partnership for its content and no way to distribute internationally, Wolk said. CBS and Verizon didn't comment.

Wolk also said 2018 will bring more virtual MVPD services, as they let providers introduce both targeted advertising and easier upgrades of interfaces than traditional MVPDs can accomplish.

The increased recognition in the past three to four years that viewers want more watching options led channels that once eschewed Internet distribution to jump to virtual MVPD lineups, said University of Michigan communications studies professor Amanda Lotz. That's been an impetus for some deals, like Disney/Fox, but smaller programmers remain unlikely to go the DTC route since sticking with a streaming service partner "takes a whole lot of headaches off the table," Lotz said. Given the technical difficulties of having a robust over-the-top (OTT) service, a more significant deal for Disney might have been its acquiring a majority of streaming tech company BAMTech (see 1708080065), she said.

The FCC's rollback of Title II regulation of broadband could sizably affect media mergers, Lotz said, with distributor and programmer relationships in the future depending on the degree to which cable ISPs engage in paid prioritization and use exclusive content deals as a selling feature. The net neutrality rollback creates the new balance of power that cable ISPs have long wanted, but content companies are in a more precarious position and more prone to look for deals with distributors, Lotz said. The new net neutrality regulatory policy "has the potential to change everything in video distribution," she said. James said it's not clear how the new net neutrality regime will affect the video industry, but ISPs like Comcast or AT&T likely won't want to be overly aggressive in favoring their own content or services, thus bringing scrutiny that could give cause for more regulation. "No one wants to poke the bear on this one," James said.

The OTT industry is still some time away from M&A deals, experts said. Streaming services are still figuring out their long-term viability, Wolk said. More likely than acquisitions are partnerships and bundles of complementary services, James said, citing Hulu and Spotify rolling out a combined offering for college students. For now, most of the existing streaming services have relatively small subscriber bases, meaning "there's not a lot to buy there," Olgeirson said.

The M&A thoughts of edge providers like Apple, Google and Facebook -- all of which undoubtedly will get deeper into video -- remain unclear, James said. The $1 billion Apple plans to spend on original content "is not that big" compared with what Netflix and Amazon Prime are spending, he said, saying shopping for an MVPD might be on hold until prices come down. The "perpetual buzz" of one of the tech companies getting into distribution has been "more noise than truth," and remains unlikely, Olgeirson said. Wolk said he sees the possibility of a major edge provider like Apple buying an MVPD or telco to get a last-mile distribution platform, plus more access to user data. Big tech companies "have more money than God," he said, saying with Apple, the question of a major investment into content, such as through buying a programmer, is "when and what, rather than if." Apple didn't comment.
